headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the United Rentals fourth quarter and full year 2014 Investor Conference call. Please be advised that this call is being recorded.Before we begin, note that the company's press release, comments made on today's call and resp
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the United Rentals fourth quarter and full year 2014 Investor Conference call. Please be advised that this call is being recorded.
Before we begin, note that the company's press release, comments made on today's call and responses to your questions contain forward-looking statements. The company's business and operations are subject to a variety of risks and uncertainties, many of which are beyond its control, and consequently, actual results may differ materially from those projected.
A summary of these uncertainties is included in the Safe Harbor statement contained in the company's earnings release. For a more complete description of these and other possible risks, please refer to the company's annual report on Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2014, as well as subsequent filings with the SEC. You can access these filings on the company's website at www.ur.com.
Please note that United Rentals has no obligation and makes no commitment to update or publicly release any revisions to forward-looking statements in order to reflect new information or subsequent events, circumstances or changes in expectation. You should also note that the company's earnings release, investor presentation and today's call include references to free cash flow, adjusted EPS, EBITDA and adjusted EBITDA, each of which is a non-GAAP term.
Speaking today for United Rentals is Michael Kneeland, Chief Executive Officer; William Plummer, Chief Financial Officer; and Matt Flannery, Chief Operating Officer.
I will now turn the call over to Mr. Kneeland. Mr. Kneeland, you may begin.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, operator and welcome, and good morning, everyone. Now I want to thank everybody for joining us on today's call. So let's get started with 2014. It was a great year for us and we think another strong year in 2015. Our message today is about progres
componenttext:
Thanks, operator and welcome, and good morning, everyone. Now I want to thank everybody for joining us on today's call. So let's get started with 2014. It was a great year for us and we think another strong year in 2015. Our message today is about progress, discipline and consistency. These fourth quarter calls tend to frame the year-end as a heart stop reality, our performance is continuum, and that's especially true this year when we went into 2015 with so much momentum.
Now I'll talk about it in a minute but first, I want to give you the last 12 months that are due because we turned in some outstanding results. Our rates were up 4.5%, in line with our guidance. 2014 was the fourth straight year we moved rates higher and we still opportunity for improvement.
We have record time utilization of 68.8% for the full year. And our return on invested capital was also a record of 8.8%.
Together, they helped drive more than $2.7 billion of adjusted EBITDA on rental revenue growth outpaced industry growth by nearly 2 to 1. And our free cash flow was a homerun for the year. This was due in part to the use of margin of 48.5%, another indication of the ongoing recovery.
When we set $1.7 billion on fleet. And as you saw last night, our CapEx plan for 2015 is approximately the same with even higher expectations for free cash flow.
Not only do we meat or beat every target in our outlook, we did it while making fundamental improvements in the way we operate. Take safe different example. In 2014, we had the fewest number of recordable injuries in our industry. And we drove our full-year recordable rate down below 1.0 for the first time.
It was the ninth consecutive year of safety improvement for us. So clearly, it's not just a flu, it's a progressive change for the better in our culture.
Especially rentals was another great story. We grew our specialty segment very effectively last year, with a disciplined mix of M&A, starts, new fleet, and cross-selling. Our full year revenue gain in specialty, which includes the acquisition of National Pump in April was approximately 83% on a gross margin of almost 51%. That's nearly 400 basis points higher than the prior year. And our fourth quarter margin for his specialty was up nearly 500 basis points.
Company-wide, all but 1 of our regions had year-over-year rental revenue growth for the quarter, with more than half of the regions showing double-digit growth. And we had a very solid increase in key account revenue, up 16% year-over-year. Financial accounts, which is a subset of our Key Accounts, grew by more than 18%. So from every perspective, very strong year.
We demanded a lot from ourselves in 2014 and I'm happy to say that we outperformed our own expectations. 
Let's talk about this year. I'm going to start by acknowledging the concerns out there about the effect of oil prices in our industry. Look, we're not running this business with bright colored glasses, and we don't plan to be caught by surprise. We've dug deep into this issue and while we haven't seen any significant attrition to date, we do expect some impact as rig counts come down. Now we're constantly pulling the field, not just to measure Upstream oil activity but possibly to gauge any knock on effect. And we did a lot of detailed analysis based on conservative assumptions to identify our exposure. And Bill is going to share some of those numbers with you in a moment.
But I could tell where they came out. Yes, we think oil prices will reduce demand for certain types of equipment in a handful of various. But we disagree very strongly with the idea that our growth is at risk.
And I'll give you 5 good reasons why we feel this way. First, Upstream oil and gas accounts for only 6% of our business company-wide. That's a very mild exposure given our fleet can be utilized on other types of customers. Given in the battlefield states, or state of Texas, we've got deep customer relationships outside of oil. Currently, more than 80% of our rig rental revenue in Texas comes from infrastructure, manufacturing, transportation, commercial building and a host of other industries. Second, we have strong systems in place for fleet management, including the relocation of equipment and a repurposing of CapEx for used sales. As circumstances change dramatically, we have the flexibility to reduce our CapEx spend for the year. We've done this before when warranted and we wouldn't hesitate to do it again.
Third, we believe that any a drag on demand for Upstream oil will be mitigated by the positive effect on other industries. Take chemical manufacturing, 1 of our key sectors. When oil prices decline, manufacturing costs drop, production is stimulated and consumer purchasing power increases. The current growth rates of the U.S. chemical industry is forecast to accelerate to at least 2016. This is just the 1 of many examples.
Fourth, our geography plays to our advantage. Our Upstream oil exposure just a fraction of our footprint in any meaningful way. Now keep in mind we serve 49 states and 10 Canadian provinces. That gives us a lot of room to deploy our assets. The reality is you've been asking us for significantly more CapEx than we spent for a few years. And we've been very disciplined in reigning in that number. So if we decided to move fleet due to localized weakness, we have the branches that are eager to take it.
And fifth, we know how to outperform our end markets, as well as our industry. We've shown you that for years. 2014, our 15% rental revenue growth is more than 3x the year-over-year growth in non-res construction to November. Thanks, in part to secular penetration. And it was nearly twice the revenue growth of our industry overall.
Not only is there's still a lot of runway ahead in the industry up-cycle, the macroeconomics is also trending in our favor. Many economists predict U.S. GDP growth will be in the range of 3% to 3.3% for 2015 with lower unemployment, more consumer spending on goods and services and return to housing starts.
And to the degree that any uncertainty still remains in our end markets, that actually works in our favor because we offer on alternative to large capital outlays. So when global insight forecast nearly 8% rental industry growth for North America in 2015 and with more growth to follow in 2016, which they did on Sunday, you can take that as a starting point. But be assured we have bigger plans.
Bottom line, this recovery has already had a share of bumps and we think oil prices will be another bump. Given our scale and diversification, we do not see this as a roadblock. In fact we think the bigger picture is that low oil prices could have a significant upside for us over time.
And more immediately, we'll keep moving forward and better-than-expected fourth quarter by making recipient investments to capture a profitable oil business. I've already mentioned that our specialty group is on a fast track. Power & HVAC in particular turned in a standout performance, with 27% same-store growth and a 61% increase in revenue overall all in 2014.
For 2015, we've earmarked $170 million or about 30% of our growth rental CapEx to meet the increasing demand for our specialty fleet. And we plan to open at least 16 new branches [indiscernible]for all of our specialty lines, Power & HVAC, Trench Safety, Pumps and Tools.
Our growth in specialty also reflects cross-selling to our broader operations where we've seen good diversity in large projects. For example, our central U.S. districts are predicting a big year for the wide range of projects underway with start dates in the next few months. This includes health care, education, hydropower, renewables, bio research and transportation to name a few.
Further West, we've got equipment on mega sites like LAX and acute major project work lined up in the Southeast, our mixed-use developments, sports arenas, theme parks and airports.
And the Northeast, our customers in high-growth verticals are hungry to up any fleet that comes available, typical many of our regions. Now I'll give you essential insight into our thinking in 2015. Our outlook is positive because the facts support it. We like what we see. We like what we hear from our customers and every indication is that the equipment rental is going to look at the multi-year up-cycle with an ongoing recovery in our end markets and a tailwind from secular penetration.
But we're also agile and we're well prepared to respond to any changes in our operating environment. We plan to spend $1.7 billion in rental CapEx this year because we believe that the demand is there. And we can adjust that number either way. And we're guiding to at least $6 billion of revenue and approximately $3 billion of adjusted EBITDA because we believe that we can hit these marks.
We've done the math, and we're already moving forward on our goals. So now we'll cover the financial results then we'll take your questions. So over to you, Bill.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike, and good morning, everyone. I'll move through the financial results pretty quickly so we can save some time to talk about the oil and gas analysis Mike mentioned and the outlook, which we want to make sure that we hit.Start with revenue. R
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike, and good morning, everyone. I'll move through the financial results pretty quickly so we can save some time to talk about the oil and gas analysis Mike mentioned and the outlook, which we want to make sure that we hit.
Start with revenue. Rental revenue was a pretty strong quarter for you, for us, as Mike mentioned, rental revenue increased 6.5%. That's $187 million year-over-year in the quarter. And as usual, I'll bridge that $187 million number. Re-rent and where we continue to be nice contributors to revenue growth for us. Re-rent and ancillary combined were up $26 million year-over-year. But the real driver's owned equipment rental revenue growth. That was up 16.3% for the quarter or $161 million year-over-year. Here are the components of that $161 million. Rental rate, up 4.1% as you saw drives about $40 million worth of year-over-year revenue improvement. Volume was up 10.7%, and that drove a $106 million worth of year-over-year revenue improvement. And that obviously includes the impact of National Pump's fleet being added to the volume calculation. Our inflation on the fleet was a headwind. It was $18 million detracting from the year-over-year change and then the rest, we'll call it mix, other, including FX was a positive $33 million. Within that $33 million, in addition to the volume that Pump brought along, Pump operates at a higher dollar utilization so they had a positive impact on mix of about $28 million within the $33 million. And then I'll also call out the effect of FX in the quarter, it was pretty significant as a headwind. About $10 million of FX detraction from our year-over-year revenue performance. The other components were a sum of a whole bunch of other this and that in the year-over-year performance. So those were the huge drivers of our revenue performance in the quarter for rental revenue. I'd also point out that we had a very robust used equipment sales results for the quarter. Used was up 16% over last year. And as importantly, the margin was also very good, 48.7% adjusted gross margin on a used equipment sales in the quarter, certainly helped to pay our continued focus on driving as much as we can through our retail channel along with the overall market price environment continues to be pretty solid in the fourth quarter. We also just touched on and had a very good new equipment sales quarter with robust growth in new equipment. 
On profitability, I'll bridge the EBITDA performance year-over-year for us. We had a company record for the fourth quarter of $775 million of adjusted EBITDA. And, likewise, it was a company record, 49.6% margin in the quarter. So that was $124 million of increase in adjusted EBITDA. And 100 basis point improvement in our margin over fourth quarter of '13. 
Here are the components of the $124 million year-over-year improvement. Rental rate improvement that I mentioned earlier for revenue drops through the EBITDA at $39 million. That's just using a 95% flow-through on the rental rate revenue dollars. Volume contributed $74 million worth of year-over-year adjusted EBITDA. And then we had a couple of other positives here. Ancillary and re-rent we mentioned along with some other small pieces contributed about $16 million. Used equipment sales, I mentioned the improvement in volume and margin there. That contributed about $14 million of improvement. And then pump, the cat class of Pumps because of their mix, contributed about $15 million worth of positive mix impact. Working against those positives, we had fleet inflation. That was about an $11 million headwind. Additional incentive comp, we had very strong incentive comp year and quarter and our adjustment to the incentive comp cost there cost us about $10 million over the prior year. Bad debt expense cost us about $8 million. We had a strong bad debt expense result in fourth quarter of '13. We had a more normalized result in '14 along with a larger AR balance. So those were the drivers there for that $8 million. Merit increases were about $6 million and all other was the remaining $1 million. So those are the components of our adjusted EBITDA change for year-over-year. If you look down at EPS. We had an adjusted EPS of $2.90 for the quarter, up very nicely from $1.59 the prior year. So all in all a very, very strong profit picture for the quarter as Mike mentioned.
Real quickly, on cash flow. We had great free cash flow performance in the quarter as well. $557 million of free cash flow the way we calculate it but I'll remind everyone that, that includes merger-related cash payments of about $17 million in the quarter. So the way we look at free cash flow in the quarter -- excuse me this is full year, full year. The way we look at free cash flow for the full year is $574 million result. The real driver there and did uncommonly strong than we expected, the real driver was their EBITDA performance alone we'd really, really strong collections. We've mentioned that before but our AR collections have been coming in very strong for the last number of must know when that was the big part of the betterment there in the free cash flow.
Just real briefly to touch on our share repurchase program. We have been repurchasing shares. We mentioned that we brought back about $102 million of shares under the new $750 million authorization in the month of December. We added to that in the month of January. To date in January, we spent extra $125 million. So we are now at $227 million of repurchases against that $750 million repurchase authorization. So that's the way for share repurchase.
Also as Mike mentioned, I'll just reiterate, we had very nice improvement in our return on invested capital, 8.8% for the full year and that's a 130 basis point improvement over the prior year with the fourth quarter sequentially improving by 40 basis points. So we feel very good about the return direction that we have the company pointed at.
And now let's talk about oil. As Michael mentioned, we've done a lot of work assessing possible impacts from low oil prices. And we've done it in a variety of different ways. We keep coming up with the same conclusion, which is that we think any reasonable expectation for impact could is manageable. Here's one way that we've taken a look at that, that we think will resonate with folks. If we look at every branch in our company that has oil and gas revenue, we decided that the best way to look at this was to model that oil and gas revenue taking a significant hit. So in this case, we said any branch would have oil and gas revenue, Upstream oil and gas revenue. The Upstream portion of their revenue stream, that facility takes a 35% hit. In addition for any branch that has more than a de minimis amount of oil and gas revenue Upstream oil and gas revenue, let's also assume that everything else all of their other revenue take a 15% hit. So they get hit 35% in oil and gas Upstream, they get it 15% for everything else. If you do that and add it all across our company, the aggregate amount of full fleet that would be freed up by those kinds of impacts would total about $400 million of average annual fleet. So $400 million relative to an $8 billion plus fleet, you could say hey, let's dismiss that, that's not significant but we don't think about it that way. $400 million is certainly a good amount of fleet to move around. Then we further ask ourselves what could it mean financially? And we made some assumptions. So the $400 million is the average annual fleet. Will that kind of an impact happen over over the full year? We said no. Let's just evaluate having that the impact build over the year and save full effect at the second half. So the second half is really where that hit would apply. So that $400 million annual impact really in calendar 2015 would only have the effect of about $200 million on a full year basis. We ask ourselves how much of that kind of a downside could we absorb, could we mitigate? And while many of us could argue that we could absorb all of that kind of a hit, we decided to be conservative in our downside analysis and assume we could only mitigate half of that. So the $200 million annual rate, we cut down to about $100 million annual impact that represented real exposure to our company. How much is that $100 million fleet worth? We assumed a dollar utilization on that, that was very high relative to the rest of our company. We used 60% in our analysis. So 60% is at least 5 percentage points higher than the dollar utilizations that we reasonably could expect at the second half for even the highest performing regions in our company. So 60% on that $100 million annually impact gives you a $60 million revenue impact and a flow of that through at 60% EBITDA, it's about a $36 million EBITDA impact.
So when you look at it in that light come it doesn't scare you, right? It's not the end of the world to say there's $36 million hole we've got to figure out a way to fill. And as we said that we think that the options are fairly conservative. The good news as Mike mentioned in his comments is that we have assessed that there is going to be robust demand in other areas outside of oil and gas and other product types that we think can help address even if this, what we believe is a downside plays out. So that's the way we're thinking about the risk from oil and gas. And if you add the $36 million impact that we just walked through to or subtract that from what we expect for the full year, we still feel like we can deliver the range of adjusted EBITDA that we've given in our guidance.
Speaking of our guidance for 2015, just to reiterate the key points you've already seen. We expect total revenue in the range of $6 billion to $6.2 billion. Within that rental revenue will be driven by rates up about 3.5% for the year and time utilization of about 59% over 20 basis point improvement last year. The adjusted EBITDA range of $295 million to $305 million again we feel is a range that represents the most likely outcome for the year. We do expect to spend about $1.7 billion of gross rental CapEx and have that net down to about $1.2 billion for the year. And free cash flow will be a very robust result for us this year. Somewhere between $725 million and $775 million is what we expect. Obviously that's significantly higher than the about $600 million number that we guided back to back in our Investor Day in December. And it really reflects the reenactment of bonus depreciation for calendar '14 that the Congress passed and President Obama signed just recently. So put it altogether and it looks like a very robust year for us. We wouldn't say that if we didn't believe that we have the ability to manage to that oil and gas release and exposure for us. But it's an opportunity as well. And we're going to look to take advantage of the opportunities that it presents as we always have. And if we can do that, we feel like we'll be having a good conversation at this time next year.
So with that, that ends our prepared comments. And we can open up the call for questions and answers. Operator?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from that line of Ted Grace from Susquehanna.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from that line of Ted Grace from Susquehanna.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was hoping to ask on 2015 margins, I know you give revenue guidance, you give EBITDA guidance and so we can back in on kind of what's implied on both on an incremental basis. Bill, maybe if you could walk through quantitatively on some of the key headwi
componenttext: I was hoping to ask on 2015 margins, I know you give revenue guidance, you give EBITDA guidance and so we can back in on kind of what's implied on both on an incremental basis. Bill, maybe if you could walk through quantitatively on some of the key headwinds or tailwinds we should just think about influencing where we might come out in that range. So things like mix, fuel costs, incentive comp, lean inflation just how of kind of give us some guideposts?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure so I'll start but certainly Mike and Matt, please chime in. As we think about top line, a couple of things that swirling in the background in our thinking. Obviously, walk through our oil and gas risk assessment but the question is did we get it, rig
componenttext: Sure so I'll start but certainly Mike and Matt, please chime in. As we think about top line, a couple of things that swirling in the background in our thinking. Obviously, walk through our oil and gas risk assessment but the question is did we get it, right? Could it be worse than that, conversely? Could it be better than that? So those are the things that surround oil and gas performance that, that may buy some -- may buy us the revenue one way or another. And I'll leave you to make your own judgment about how much risk you think there is. FX is another factor that we certainly needed to be aware of. The Canadian dollar has been weakening pretty consistently. Average Canadian was down last year by about 6% to 7% year and right now, as we said, if it's flat line from where it sits right now at about $0.81 U.S., that would be another 6% or so year-over-year headwind from the currency going down. So that's a nontrivial amount of revenue that could erode. The guidance we give is total revenue. So you have to be mindful of used and new as well. And our plan for used equipment sales this year is a reduction over what we achieved in 2014. Just look at the difference between gross CapEx and net rental CapEx, we're guiding to something like $500 million of used sales proceeds that compares to $549 million this year or in '14. So that will be a little bit of an impact to the revenues and maybe keeps the revenue guidance from being higher than it is. And then there are other items that, that might impact at the adjusted EBITDA line. So for example, we had a very robust incentive compensation year this year. And when we reset the incentive comp targets for 2015, our baseline plan assumes that we hit target and only payout at target. We paid out nicely above target this year. So that will impact the positive way where we might end up on the adjusted EBITDA line. And a host of other issues. You mentioned Lean. The Lean initiatives are still rolling out and building momentum. We finished the quarter still a little bit maxed under here. We finished the year at an annualized run rate of about $30 million of Lean impact. That's up from the $23 million that we reported at the end of the third quarter. So that's another factor that playing through our expectations for 2015. So I'll stop there and again, Mike and Matt, you guys want to add anything if I've forgotten anything, please?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well I think captured it, Bill. It's important to note the difference in used sales is really about what about has reached its rental useful life in the year and we don't have as much of fleet that we have to sell. So that's why we're guiding lower there.
componenttext: Well I think captured it, Bill. It's important to note the difference in used sales is really about what about has reached its rental useful life in the year and we don't have as much of fleet that we have to sell. So that's why we're guiding lower there. If retail opportunities go over and above that, or we'll make swings but I think it's a good pace at where we want to move out there we want to keep our fleet fresh and to the targets we set.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would add that everything that Bill and Matt said are spot on and I think when you look at the projections of the industry at 8% for North America is a little bit higher than what we've experienced or what they've projected in '14. So could there be som
componenttext: I would add that everything that Bill and Matt said are spot on and I think when you look at the projections of the industry at 8% for North America is a little bit higher than what we've experienced or what they've projected in '14. So could there be some on rate, could there be opportunities, could be. We don't know to really to somewhat tempered it as we blend for the oil. But that could be an upside for us going forward.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: What I would point at is I know where you're going, right. You're looking at the midpoint of revenue and EBITDA and say, hey, sellthrough there comes out at a pretty high-level, 6% to 8-plus percent. That's an artifact of the fact that we're using ranges
componenttext: What I would point at is I know where you're going, right. You're looking at the midpoint of revenue and EBITDA and say, hey, sellthrough there comes out at a pretty high-level, 6% to 8-plus percent. That's an artifact of the fact that we're using ranges and the fact that the flow-through calculation is very sensitive. If we were at at point blank, we would still say that we think about flow-through for 2015 being something like 60% would toward the upside because of the net effect of all of the things that I mentioned earlier. So if you're modeling I'd say get your revenue where you want it, you're 50% then maybe put your thumb and scale a little bit higher to reflect some of the net benefits that we expect to accrue over the course of the year.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015

componenttext: That super helpful. The only follow-up I have is any willingness to quantify kind of what Lean expectations are? I know you exited a run rate of 30, you're targeting 100-plus to the program over a few years but any chance could you just calibrate us on what the tailwind will might look like this year?

componenttext: Well you could do the trends. This is Matt. I mean we'd expect it to follow that trend, right? We set external -- I mean, internal targets above that for '15 [ph]. We've even put extra emphasis on it this year but I feel comfortable that we'll keep a steady pace towards $100 million by the end of '16.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Justin Jordan from Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Justin Jordan from Jefferies.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just want to talk about the nice problem of having extra free cash flow and what that might mean in terms of changes or what you're thinking about capital allocation in calendar '15? Because obviously relative to the guidance you gave on December 4, ess
componenttext: I just want to talk about the nice problem of having extra free cash flow and what that might mean in terms of changes or what you're thinking about capital allocation in calendar '15? Because obviously relative to the guidance you gave on December 4, essentially you've increased free cash flow guidance by 25% overnight. Now I appreciate there's a tax implication here it's not really that much a percentage gain. But is it that changing how you're thinking about potential specialty M&A? Is that changing how you think about deleveraging or potentially changing how you think about the amount of stock repurchasing you might do in '15?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Do you want to give any more color than that?
componenttext: Do you want to give any more color than that?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, you get one question. I think that the what M&A is that we're always looking at M&A opportunities and I don't think it changes how we think about M&A. If we found the right M&A opportunity, then we would go ahead and do that whether we were at $600 mi
componenttext: No, you get one question. I think that the what M&A is that we're always looking at M&A opportunities and I don't think it changes how we think about M&A. If we found the right M&A opportunity, then we would go ahead and do that whether we were at $600 million or $700 million or $775 million of free cash flow. So M&A wouldn't change. Is it fair to say that as we look at that share repurchase program, if you got more cash flow and you want to pass the leverage and we've already said we expect to be toward the low end of the leverage range that we want to operate in by the end of this year. We've called it $2.6  billion as the leverage ratio we expect before the increase in free cash flow. So I think that we would be more inclined to say okay, let's not go crazy and go below the 2.5 kind of leverage ratio this year now that we've got more cash flow coming in. So that may change how we think about the timing of the share repurchase program. And I think that's a sensible way to think about it. So that's all still to be discussed. And certainly, we'll talk about it more as we make more decisions. But I'd say M&A doesn't change but everything else we kind of put in, in the mix and say okay, we've got an extra $100 million, what do you want to do with it and we'll make that call.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from that line of Seth Weber from RBC capital.
componenttext: Our next question comes from that line of Seth Weber from RBC capital.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to talk about your CapEx commentary, specifically the comments around flexibility, around CapEx and you kept the $1.7 billion gross number for the year. Should we think about cadence this year being similar to how it's been in the prior year, so
componenttext: I wanted to talk about your CapEx commentary, specifically the comments around flexibility, around CapEx and you kept the $1.7 billion gross number for the year. Should we think about cadence this year being similar to how it's been in the prior year, so 60% to 65% in the first half? Or do you hold back some of the spending to wait and see how the markets evolve? That's my first question. And then kind of as an add on to that, I mean, it sounds like your specialty as a percentage of your growth capital is down. I think last year it was something like I don't know, 270, 280, something like that, now it's 170, I think you said. Is that reduction primarily focused on the pump business? Or how should we think about your cap growth capital going towards the specialty category?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Seth. I'll answer the first question. As far as the cadence, if we plan out to being similar to this year, you know that we have really strong flexibility as far as we don't need to make a decision how we're going to ship until literally a week befo
componenttext: Sure, Seth. I'll answer the first question. As far as the cadence, if we plan out to being similar to this year, you know that we have really strong flexibility as far as we don't need to make a decision how we're going to ship until literally a week before it's going to ship. So the second quarter by April I think we'll get very good feel of what the second quarter is going to be more or less and it will all be demand driven. The first quarter is light already, which is good for us and right now we're restricting the inflow of CapEx obviously in the market set we think may have a little bit of softening in demand in the back half the year. So I really think we'll get a better picture on how much we adjust for more norm and I would call last year's cadence a new norm. Depending on what the demand is and when we're we're getting the returns and where our customers need our services. So that's always been about a cadence. As far as the specialty, we spent -- we plan on spending over 30% of our growth capital on specialty. You're talking about more of a gross number when you're referring to last year's number and a lot of that was I would say re-fleeting the pump, right. So we need that acquisition to grow. And fleeting up the many cold starts that we've done in our other specialty segments specifically power even the year before. So they were now ready to absorb scale. So we really pushed a lot into the cold starts over the last couple of years. And we'll do some more cold starts this year but not at the scale that we did over the past 2 years.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, sorry, Matt, is my math is incorrect I thought your specialty last year represented like half of the growth capital or something like that?
componenttext: Okay, sorry, Matt, is my math is incorrect I thought your specialty last year represented like half of the growth capital or something like that?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Mike. You're close to that number. To Matt's point, if you go back to '13, we had a significant amount of our cold starts, stock that we're in, in the later part of the fourth quarter that a lot of that CapEx ran into 2014 and then the cold starts
componenttext: This is Mike. You're close to that number. To Matt's point, if you go back to '13, we had a significant amount of our cold starts, stock that we're in, in the later part of the fourth quarter that a lot of that CapEx ran into 2014 and then the cold starts we have for the course of the year and then freeing all of those as we went through the year. So in total numbers, it's down. You're right here but it hasn't changed our view on specialty. We do reserve the right on pump to understand what impact Upstream could or could not have as we go through our cross-sell opportunities. And we have, as I mentioned, we will do cold starts with pump to broaden their reach and that was 1 of the key aspects of the acquisition was making sure that if you recall, 6% of their business was only in our commercial and industrial space. So we see that as a significant opportunity. So it's kind of more of a tempered look, take a look at it. And as I also mentioned, if there's a need for more growth capital, we've got it, and we'll do it. The flexibility is built into our model.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, and Matt, have you seen anything can you make any comments on used equipment pricing because I think that's something that people are increasingly nervous about?
componenttext: Okay, and Matt, have you seen anything can you make any comments on used equipment pricing because I think that's something that people are increasingly nervous about?

componenttext: Well other than that, [indiscernible] so we enjoyed a real robust fourth quarter from a volume a little bit more than what we expected in the month of December and with margins holding flat. So and flat at a very high-level. So we're seeing still robust used equipment margins.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of David Raso from Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of David Raso from Evercore ISI.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: On the downside scenario, I was just curious, what percent of your entire fleet is captured and what you're considering at risk territories? And then secondarily, just trying to think through rental rates that scenario, just trying to capture if you feel
componenttext: On the downside scenario, I was just curious, what percent of your entire fleet is captured and what you're considering at risk territories? And then secondarily, just trying to think through rental rates that scenario, just trying to capture if you feel there's any potential knock-on effect to rates in territories where other equipment might be going into or essentially just given the rate pressure you may see in those weaker energy-sensitive markets?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I'll tackle the rate 1 first. The 3.5, about 3.5 guidance that we gave is lower than where we were thinking about rate, call it a month ago or 2 months ago. And so in that sense we have included some conservatism to reflect the fact that rate could be
componenttext: So I'll tackle the rate 1 first. The 3.5, about 3.5 guidance that we gave is lower than where we were thinking about rate, call it a month ago or 2 months ago. And so in that sense we have included some conservatism to reflect the fact that rate could be pressured as that oil and gas dynamic plays out. And yet we still think 3.5. Could it be worse than that? Obviously, it could. But again, we think we've got opportunities to respond and manage it down. I don't remember off the top of my head the first question what are some of the fleet?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: If you just do the math right, we said a 35% knock on I mean, a 35% Upstream would net in and about $400 million. So it's over $1 billion I'd say it's somewhere in $1 billion or $1.2 billion I don't have the number right in front of me but I think that th
componenttext: If you just do the math right, we said a 35% knock on I mean, a 35% Upstream would net in and about $400 million. So it's over $1 billion I'd say it's somewhere in $1 billion or $1.2 billion I don't have the number right in front of me but I think that the last [indiscernible] it's probably $1.2 billion of fleet with will be impacted and those are in markets that have oil and gas Upstream business today.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, I may be oversimplifying you because not everthing in these states are driven by energy so obviously about 29% of your branches, not all branches are the same, I know that but just going through the data we have 29% of branches are in what I'd con
componenttext: I mean, I may be oversimplifying you because not everthing in these states are driven by energy so obviously about 29% of your branches, not all branches are the same, I know that but just going through the data we have 29% of branches are in what I'd consider nearly some more energy-sensitive states and the oil sands decline in your analysis you are seeing kind of for roughly half of that at risk I guess right because $1.2 billion of the $8.44 billion of fleet is about 14%, is that the right way to think of it roughly? Half of the branches in those states in oil sands is sort of at risk? I'm just trying to understand the analysis.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's hard to do the analysis based on branches and states and get anything useful in our opinion. That's why we went to the individual location. And tried to reason from what business they have that's exposed right here and now. So we didn't do it to
componenttext: Yes, it's hard to do the analysis based on branches and states and get anything useful in our opinion. That's why we went to the individual location. And tried to reason from what business they have that's exposed right here and now. So we didn't do it to go to great levels of detail on how how many branches or in which states. We have that. I don't know that it's something we want to go through in great detail. But just $400 million impact I think really does capture a pretty good view of what the exposure might be. But if you don't believe it, okay, make it a $500 million impact, let's say, we're off by 25% or even a $600 million impact and say we're off by 50%. The end result doesn't change dramatically, right? It's still a $35 million, $45 million, $50 million kind of risk even with conservative assumptions about how far down it goes and how much we can mitigate. I like our chances with that kind of risk scenario.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, it appreciate it. I think the issue is, is there more territories at risk than solely branches that happen to have Upstream oil and gas in their region? I mean, it's obviously just debate right now about and beyond just those direct areas and also on
componenttext: No, it appreciate it. I think the issue is, is there more territories at risk than solely branches that happen to have Upstream oil and gas in their region? I mean, it's obviously just debate right now about and beyond just those direct areas and also on the rates, I mean, you've done a great job this cycle on saying we're not going to throw capital up the fleet just to grow. We're going to focus on better returns. Should I expect if I'm thinking maybe more cautious about the impact and great broader contagion, you're going to hold the rate before you try to hold utilization? I mean, if I had the model some downside sensitivity, should I be taking it more down on utilization, you'd argue? Or taking down on the rate. I'm just trying to get a feel for philosophically if things got weaker than you're forecasting?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, all right. I'm sorry, Matt, I'll let you...
componenttext: Yes, all right. I'm sorry, Matt, I'll let you...

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, it will depend right on what the demand is and what we're seeing it but I would say that we're going to have utilization at the level that it needs to be at because we can do -- we can manage that. We can manage how much fleet we put into the market a
componenttext: No, it will depend right on what the demand is and what we're seeing it but I would say that we're going to have utilization at the level that it needs to be at because we can do -- we can manage that. We can manage how much fleet we put into the market and how much fleet we remove out of the market. So I think we'll be very diligent on those rate and time to time it's much more easily manageable. And I think as Bill stated we can built in a little conservatism on the rate because moving a fleet from higher rate areas and your growth fleet into areas that aren't your top 10% is going to have some knock point of risk 0.25 of a point, 0.50 a point, I don't think we really know yet but if we captured in our guidance.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Then I guess what I'll take from that then if you there's some utilization's coming or some pressure while you want to hold rate, might play with it a bit, but the key is you also have the outlet valve of I'm just going to sell fleet. I mean, I guess that
componenttext: Then I guess what I'll take from that then if you there's some utilization's coming or some pressure while you want to hold rate, might play with it a bit, but the key is you also have the outlet valve of I'm just going to sell fleet. I mean, I guess that's the idea used price hold up, you can manage utilization also by just simply shutting some fleet and I think that's the key issue of used prices, if they hold out, you can do that relatively profitably but that's obviously part of the debate. So we should think of let's just try to move the fleet, you also can tap the retail market the best you can on sell and used.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thank you, David. Thank you.
componenttext: Yes. Thank you, David. Thank you.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015

componenttext: I've got a question on your construction pipeline on Slide 13. And I just want to tie that together maybe with your methodology on guidance. So how should be thinking about $370 billion pipeline and how you incorporate that into your guidance and then maybe just to take it 1 step further, what are your guys in the ground telling for some of these energy-sensitive projects that have already started or maybe are just a few months away from breaking ground? Are they concerned about this? Are they thinking everything kind of moves forward as planned?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Matt, Joe. We do have some key account managers that specifically call on oil and gas. So obviously, they are hearing the most noise about, whether it's future concerns or some job cancellations. But even in that space, the pipeline was so robust
componenttext: This is Matt, Joe. We do have some key account managers that specifically call on oil and gas. So obviously, they are hearing the most noise about, whether it's future concerns or some job cancellations. But even in that space, the pipeline was so robust that individually, they may have opportunity. I think more importantly, the other 90% of our key account managers are extremely encouraged because we've always said the fleet to the highest return opportunity and oil and was pretty hot for a while. You could argue we may have underserved a lot of other opportunity that will give us very good returns and a little bit more geographically dispersed. So I think that what we're hearing on the ground is encouragement and opportunity in markets like the West Coast, even the Northwest or Southeast, the mid-Atlantic, where you could the map we have on the investor I think it was Slide 14, where you see there's some real big opportunities. So that's what we're hearing, that's why we feel very store about our guidance, our customers have the demand and our boots on the ground are seeing.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Scott Schneeberger from Oppenheimer.

componenttext: I'll follow up on Joe's question. On Slide 14, that is, it's nice construction overall, it that nonres construction, could you specify? And then could you speak to the end markets in those 6 or 7 stays where you see double-digit growth?

componenttext: No, you said the states on Slide 14, the vertical opportunities in those states and what type of construction specifically?

componenttextpreview: So, I think Mike covered a little bit of it in his opening remarks. When I say it's broad, it's broad. I mean, there are multiple states, multiple planned expansions, manufacturing. I'd say the single largest vertical would probably be chemical. Chemical
componenttext: So, I think Mike covered a little bit of it in his opening remarks. When I say it's broad, it's broad. I mean, there are multiple states, multiple planned expansions, manufacturing. I'd say the single largest vertical would probably be chemical. Chemical expenses have shown robust growth. Even the state of Texas, right? We talked a lot about the contagion impact in Texas. We have a very large push of our business in Texas that's chemical-related. And that's forecasted to be 26% growth in Texas. So we think that there's many verticals that are positive in places that we're going to serving 2015. And it's that broad base just I mean chemical stands out at just how much growth is, which is why I'm not holding any other vertical because it's very broad.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just following up on that, how much is that is forecast and how much do you fill this in hand at this point of the year?
componenttext: Just following up on that, how much is that is forecast and how much do you fill this in hand at this point of the year?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I don't have to put in place front of me right now but you would think about it as the through the seasons of the year. And certainly, there's less start right now although our time is very strong. I would say by mid-summer you're going to see at least
componenttext: So I don't have to put in place front of me right now but you would think about it as the through the seasons of the year. And certainly, there's less start right now although our time is very strong. I would say by mid-summer you're going to see at least half of the pipeline materialize in rental opportunity. So and then it's just a matter of how things move from it and that's standard with the construction cycle that we've been experiencing throughout my career.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: A question just on the potential risk of accelerated fleet growth across the industry with what is a pretty strong backdrop and really your ability to monitor what your competitors are doing and if there's any particular competitor segment, whether that's
componenttext: A question just on the potential risk of accelerated fleet growth across the industry with what is a pretty strong backdrop and really your ability to monitor what your competitors are doing and if there's any particular competitor segment, whether that's the region are size of competitor, that you think would be the largest risk to maybe over exaggerating fleet growth and adding some rental rate price pressure?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I'll start. The ability to monitor is pretty good, right? We're everywhere and we touch customer but a lot of the market. And so we've got realtime intelligence and what our competitors are doing. And we feel we have the ability to respond if we t
componenttext: Yes, so I'll start. The ability to monitor is pretty good, right? We're everywhere and we touch customer but a lot of the market. And so we've got realtime intelligence and what our competitors are doing. And we feel we have the ability to respond if we think responding is appropriate and that's probably the advantages of being who we are. In terms of what competitor might be most at risk? We won't names here. I'll leave you to make your own judgment about that. All we can say is that United Rentals is going to be very conscious about any type of decision, whether it's increase or decrease and it's going to be driven by what we're taking from the market. [indiscernible]

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jerry Revich from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jerry Revich from Goldman Sachs.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Can you gentlemen talk about what you're hearing from you refining customers? I think that was 1 of our bigger industrial end markets. If I remember their disclosures, right, we've seen them cut back in CapEx but I think the equipment's been more on the m
componenttext: Can you gentlemen talk about what you're hearing from you refining customers? I think that was 1 of our bigger industrial end markets. If I remember their disclosures, right, we've seen them cut back in CapEx but I think the equipment's been more on the maintenance side of everyday type work is that right? Can you give us an update for that end market?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Certainly. So we have heard some CapEx cutbacks and I would say probably more severe in the oil sands than anywhere else. And there have been a couple of projects in the Gulf that have been canceled but I would say overall that pipeline's still robust any
componenttext: Certainly. So we have heard some CapEx cutbacks and I would say probably more severe in the oil sands than anywhere else. And there have been a couple of projects in the Gulf that have been canceled but I would say overall that pipeline's still robust anywhere accurate a large amount of onset of relationships that we acquired during the merger with RSC really, really gives us a strong base to work from. We're not seeing any slowdown of that maintenance at all. As a matter of fact, our industrial region is showing the highest time utilization we have in the company right now and the highest year-over-year growth. And they're primarily on-site on what I would call a downstream oil and gas and chemical plants and we're just seeing real strong growth there and I don't think that maintenance is going to take a hit here. I think it's mostly capital spend, which if we really what there's certainly an opportunity there for us to get more penetration as capital continues to get caught from some of the end markets.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was going to say also on our slide, our customer confidence index, reaching out only, of the 170 Key Accounts were reached out to, only 1% saw a slower growth in 2015. We spend an awful lot of time in preparation for this call reaching out to our custom
componenttext: I was going to say also on our slide, our customer confidence index, reaching out only, of the 170 Key Accounts were reached out to, only 1% saw a slower growth in 2015. We spend an awful lot of time in preparation for this call reaching out to our customers, reaching out to our employees. I know more about oil in the last 2 weeks than my 35 years in the industry. And I would tell you that we haven't seen any significant impact talking to our customer's steel erectors. Steel erectors, when you take a look at their book of business and bidding, not 1 of the projects I saw had any relationship to oil at all. And they would say it's a record opportunity and year for them coming up on their bidding requirements. So that alone was the general -- was the feedback that we're getting from ARA and Global Insight, which by the way has been inside this industry for close to 7 years, maybe longer, working with our industry, refining the nuances of their model on how this industry reacts to things. When they come out with 8%, we take that to heart and that's not soft, that's not easy. And we think that, that's a good indication of where our industry's going.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Matt, just a clarification, if you don't mind. The cancellations that you mentioned, was that ground-up projects that you're referring to or is that just brownfield type work?
componenttext: And Matt, just a clarification, if you don't mind. The cancellations that you mentioned, was that ground-up projects that you're referring to or is that just brownfield type work?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ground-up projects. So there are a couple of plants. I mean the pipeline that we went through in our fourth quarter QBRs with our regions, we saw more projects start with $1 billion than I've seen in the last couple of years combined. And candidly, half o
componenttext: Ground-up projects. So there are a couple of plants. I mean the pipeline that we went through in our fourth quarter QBRs with our regions, we saw more projects start with $1 billion than I've seen in the last couple of years combined. And candidly, half of those projects got I think a more robust pipeline than we had over the past years as far as large projects. And we have seen maybe 10% of those get caught off the table right now because concerns everybody has. So they hold back on some of these new construction, new capital projects but it's -- I still feel the pipeline as Mike stated and Bill stated very robust and the Global Internet survey just kind of supports what we're hearing from customers and from our boots on the ground.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Steven Fisher from UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Steven Fisher from UBS.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: How would you guys describe your expectations for Canada overall in 2015 relative to the U.S. I know you just mentioned some oil sands, the weakness, but just Canada overall. I mean how is easy to reallocate the pavement from Canada to the U.S.? Or would
componenttext: How would you guys describe your expectations for Canada overall in 2015 relative to the U.S. I know you just mentioned some oil sands, the weakness, but just Canada overall. I mean how is easy to reallocate the pavement from Canada to the U.S.? Or would you renovation reallocating amongst the provinces?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll start and I'll ask Matt to tie in. As part of the overall review with ARA, they're looking at a little over 3% growth for all of Canada. That combines with the 8.5% they're projecting for the U.S. that would give them just around 8%, 8.1% growth for
componenttext: I'll start and I'll ask Matt to tie in. As part of the overall review with ARA, they're looking at a little over 3% growth for all of Canada. That combines with the 8.5% they're projecting for the U.S. that would give them just around 8%, 8.1% growth for North America. I actually think that Eastern Canada, which by the way has been down for the last several years, we'll see some activity there and come forward. The only headwind we would have, as Bill mentioned, is the currency exchange from a revenue but on a constant dollars, we would expect that to grow. So we see that -- the Canadian market grow and probably less growth on Western Canada and we've experienced in the past.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would agree, Mike. We'll just stay in same currency, right, that's the way I would manage those businesses and judge them. We will see growth in both of those both Western and Eastern Canada regions next year. And like all of our regions, we do 0 growth
componenttext: I would agree, Mike. We'll just stay in same currency, right, that's the way I would manage those businesses and judge them. We will see growth in both of those both Western and Eastern Canada regions next year. And like all of our regions, we do 0 growth CapEx budgets so they're going to have to earn their growth as they stack rank against their peers and they fared pretty well in the past and I expect them to fare pretty well in the future, specifically Western Canada.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And in terms of reallocating equipment between Canada and the U.S., is that something you would envision doing and how easy is that?
componenttext: And in terms of reallocating equipment between Canada and the U.S., is that something you would envision doing and how easy is that?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think because we have -- when you think about the $1.7 billion of capital that we spend, that's 20% of a late $24 billion base, if we start with this year's base. We've historically been able to reship geographically by utilizing equipment sales in eith
componenttext: I think because we have -- when you think about the $1.7 billion of capital that we spend, that's 20% of a late $24 billion base, if we start with this year's base. We've historically been able to reship geographically by utilizing equipment sales in either not replacing in that market, not putting growth capital in that market. So we've been able to geographically remix through that. If we had to put trucks on their fleet, we'd do that and if there are some instances of doing it for Western Canada but if it was really dropping that's not something we would do. The cost costs are minimal compared to the opportunity you'd have by reallocating. But right now, they're running high time utilization and we're just going to manage the influx in the energy, oil and gas markets first and I think that will prevent them from having to move fleet but we can react very quickly, whether it's in Canada or somewhere else to move fleet.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our final question due to time constraints comes from the line of Nicole DeBlase from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And our final question due to time constraints comes from the line of Nicole DeBlase from Morgan Stanley.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So just -- most of mine have been answered, but just 1 on utilization. So I was kind of surprised to see that you were to see that you were guiding for flattish utilization in '15. Is that also conservatism around oil and gas risk or are we kind of at the
componenttext: So just -- most of mine have been answered, but just 1 on utilization. So I was kind of surprised to see that you were to see that you were guiding for flattish utilization in '15. Is that also conservatism around oil and gas risk or are we kind of at the high water mark for utilization this cycle?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't say we're at the high water mark. We still feel we've got opportunities to continue to drive utilization. We've talked in the past of all 3 of us probably remain that we can get in the 70s if the market holds and if we do the things that we thi
componenttext: I wouldn't say we're at the high water mark. We still feel we've got opportunities to continue to drive utilization. We've talked in the past of all 3 of us probably remain that we can get in the 70s if the market holds and if we do the things that we think we can do. The 59% would be up 20 basis points so I guess you could call that flat if you like. But that is tempered somewhat like the rate discussion's tempered somewhat by our concern about oil and gas and about while we think we can mitigate, we don't know that we will be able to mitigate 100% of any oil and gas often. And so we back off a little a bit from where we were a month or 2 ago in our talk about 2015 but we still think that, that's a very robust performance on utilization. And Matt's comments earlier, utilization is something that we certainly have lots of levers that we can use, right? If it's falling down, you can't sell more or you can buy less. And for every business you do have over fleet. So we think that we can pull all of the appropriate levers and deliver that about 69% and we think that's a step on the way towards better utilization over the next several years.
