headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the United Rentals fourth quarter and full year 2014 Investor Conference call. Please be advised that this call is being recorded.Before we begin, note that the company's press release, comments made on today's call and resp
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the United Rentals fourth quarter and full year 2014 Investor Conference call. Please be advised that this call is being recorded.
Before we begin, note that the company's press release, comments made on today's call and responses to your questions contain forward-looking statements. The company's business and operations are subject to a variety of risks and uncertainties, many of which are beyond its control, and consequently, actual results may differ materially from those projected.
A summary of these uncertainties is included in the Safe Harbor statement contained in the company's earnings release. For a more complete description of these and other possible risks, please refer to the company's annual report on Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2014, as well as subsequent filings with the SEC. You can access these filings on the company's website at www.ur.com.
Please note that United Rentals has no obligation and makes no commitment to update or publicly release any revisions to forward-looking statements in order to reflect new information or subsequent events, circumstances or changes in expectation. You should also note that the company's earnings release, investor presentation and today's call include references to free cash flow, adjusted EPS, EBITDA and adjusted EBITDA, each of which is a non-GAAP term.
Speaking today for United Rentals is Michael Kneeland, Chief Executive Officer; William Plummer, Chief Financial Officer; and Matt Flannery, Chief Operating Officer.
I will now turn the call over to Mr. Kneeland. Mr. Kneeland, you may begin.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, operator, and welcome, and good morning, everyone. Now I want to thank everybody for joining us on today's call. So let's get started with 2014. It was a great year for us and we think another strong year in 2015. Our message today is about progre
componenttext:
Thanks, operator, and welcome, and good morning, everyone. Now I want to thank everybody for joining us on today's call. So let's get started with 2014. It was a great year for us and we think another strong year in 2015. Our message today is about progress, discipline and consistency. These fourth quarter calls tend to frame the year-end as a heart stop, but in reality, our performance is a continuum, and that's especially true this year when we went into 2015 with so much momentum.
Now I'll talk about it in a minute, but first, I want to give you the last 12 months that are due because we turned in some outstanding results. Our rates were up 4.5%, in line with our guidance. 2014 was the fourth straight year we moved rates higher and we still see opportunity for improvement.
We have record time utilization of 68.8% for the full year. And our return on invested capital was also a record of 8.8%.
Together, they helped drive more than $2.7 billion of adjusted EBITDA on rental revenue growth outpaced the industry growth by nearly 2:1. And our free cash flow was a home run for the year. This was due in part to the use of margin of 48.5%, another indication of the ongoing recovery.
And we set $1.7 billion on fleet. And as you saw last night, our CapEx plan for 2015 is approximately the same with even higher expectations for free cash flow.
Not only do we meet or beat every target in our outlook, we did it while making fundamental improvements in the way we operate. Take safety for an example. In 2014, we had the fewest number of recordable injuries in our history. And we drove our full-year recordable rate down below 1.0 for the first time.
It was the ninth consecutive year of safety improvement for us. So clearly, it's not just a fluke, it's a progressive change for the better in our culture.
Specialty rentals was another great story. We grew our specialty segment very effectively last year, with a disciplined mix of MA, cold starts, new fleet and cross-selling. Our full year revenue gain in specialty, which includes the acquisition of National Pump in April was approximately 83% and a gross margin of almost 51%. That's nearly 400 basis points higher than the prior year. And our fourth quarter margin for  specialty was up nearly 500 basis points.
Company-wide, all but 1 of our regions had year-over-year rental revenue growth for the quarter, with more than half of the regions showing double-digit growth. And we had a very solid increase in key account revenue, up 16% year-over-year. Financial accounts, which is a subset of our key accounts, grew by more than 18%. So from every perspective, very strong year.
We demanded a lot of ourselves in 2014 and I'm happy to say that we outperformed our own expectations. 
Let's talk about this year. I'm going to start by acknowledging the concerns out there about the effect of oil prices on our industry. Look, we're not running this business with bright-colored glasses and we don't plan to be caught by surprise. We've dug deep into this issue and while we haven't seen any significant attrition to date, we do expect some impact as rig counts come down. Now we're constantly pulling the field not just to measure upstream oil activity but also to gauge any knock-on effect. And we did a lot of detailed analysis based on conservative assumptions to identify our exposure. And Bill is going to share some of those numbers with you in a moment.
But I can tell where they came out. Yes, we think oil prices will reduce demand for certain types of equipment in a handful of areas. But we disagree very strongly with the idea that our growth is at risk.
And I'll give you 5 good reasons why we feel this way. First, upstream oil and gas accounts for only 6% of our business company-wide. That's a very modest exposure given our fleet can be utilized by other types of customers. Even in the battlefield states, or State of Texas, we've got deep customer relationships outside of oil. Currently, more than 80% of our rig rental revenue in Texas comes from infrastructure, manufacturing, transportation, commercial building and a host of other industries. Second, we have strong systems in place for fleet management, including the relocation of equipment and a repurposing of CapEx through used sales. And as circumstances change dramatically, we have the flexibility to reduce our CapEx spend for the year. We've done this before when warranted and we wouldn't hesitate to do it again. Third, we believe that any drag on demand for upstream oil will be mitigated by the positive effect on other industries. Take chemical manufacturing, 1 of our key sectors. When oil prices decline, manufacturing costs drop, production is stimulated and consumer purchasing power increases. The current growth rate for the U.S. chemical industry is forecast to accelerate to at least 2016. This is just 1 of many examples. Fourth, our geography plays to our advantage. Our upstream oil exposure touches just a fraction of our footprint in any meaningful way. Now keep in mind, we serve 49 states and 10 Canadian provinces. That gives us a lot of room to deploy our assets. The reality is a few has been asking us for significantly more CapEx than we spent for a few years now, and we've been very disciplined in reigning in that number. So if we decided to move fleet due to localized weakness, we have branches that are eager to take it.
And fifth, we know how to outperform our end markets as well as our industry. We've shown you that for years. 2014, our 15% rental revenue growth was more than 3x the year-over-year growth in non-res construction through November, thanks in part to secular penetration. And it was nearly twice the revenue growth of our industry overall.
Not only is there's still lot of runway ahead in the industry up-cycle, the macroeconomy is also trending in our favor. Many economists predict U.S. GDP growth will be in the range of 3% to 3.3% for 2015, with lower unemployment, more consumer spending on goods and services and return to housing starts. And to the degree that any uncertainty still remains in our end markets, that actually works in our favor because we offer on alternative to large capital outlays. 
So when global insight forecast nearly 8% rental industry growth for North America in 2015, and with more growth to follow in 2016, which they did on Sunday, you can take that as a starting point. But be assured, we have bigger plans.
Bottom line, this recovery has already had a share of bumps and we think oil prices will be another bump. Given our scale and diversification, we do not see this as a roadblock. In fact, we think the bigger picture is that low oil prices could have a significant upside for us over time.
And more immediately, we'll keep moving forward with better-than-expected fourth quarter by making disciplined investments to capture a profitable business. I've already mentioned that our specialty group is on a fast track. Power & HVAC in particular turned in a standout performance, with 27% same-store growth and a 61% increase in revenue overall all in 2014.
For 2015, we've earmarked $170 million or about 30% of our growth rental CapEx to meet the increasing demand for our specialty fleet. And we plan to open at least 16 new branches, this includes [indiscernible] for all of our specialty lines, Power & HVAC, Trench Safety, Pumps and Tools.
Our growth in specialty also reflects cross-selling to our broader operations where we're seeing good diversity in large projects. For example, our central U.S. districts are predicting a big year with a wide range of projects underway, with start dates in the next few months. This includes health care, education, hydropower, renewables, bio research and transportation, to name a few.
Further West, we've got equipment on mega sites like LAX and a queue of major project work lined up in the Southeast for mixed-use developments, sports arenas, theme parks and airports.
And in the Northeast, our customers in high-growth verticals are hungry to [indiscernible] any fleet that comes available, atypical in many of our regions. 
Now how about I give you a substantial insight into our thinking in 2015. Our outlook is positive because the facts support it. We like what we see. We like what we hear from our customers and every indication is that the equipment rental is going to look at a multiyear up-cycle with an ongoing recovery in our end markets and a tailwind from secular penetration.
But we're also agile and we're well-prepared to respond to any changes in our operating environment. We plan to spend $1.7 billion in rental CapEx this year because we believe the demand is there. And we can adjust that number either way. And we're guiding to at least $6 billion of revenue and approximately $3 billion of adjusted EBITDA because we believe that we can hit these marks.
We've done the math and we're already moving forward on our goals. So now, Bill will cover the financial results and then we'll take your questions. So over to you, Bill.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike, and good morning to everyone. I'll move through the financial results pretty quickly so we can save some time to talk about the oil and gas analysis Mike mentioned, and the outlook, which we want to make sure that we hit.Start with revenue
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike, and good morning to everyone. I'll move through the financial results pretty quickly so we can save some time to talk about the oil and gas analysis Mike mentioned, and the outlook, which we want to make sure that we hit.
Start with revenue. Rental revenue was a pretty strong quarter for you -- for us, as Mike mentioned, total rental revenue increased 6.5%. That's $187 million year-over-year in the quarter. And as usual, I'll bridge that $187 million number. Re-rent and ancillary continue to be nice contributors to revenue growth for us. Re-rent and ancillary combined were up $26 million year-over-year. But the real driver is owned equipment rental revenue growth. That was up 16.3% for the quarter or $161 million year-over-year. Here are the components of that $161 million. Rental rate, up 4.1%, as you saw, drives about $40 million worth of year-over-year revenue improvement. Volume was up 10.7%, and that drove $106 million worth of year-over-year revenue improvement and that obviously includes the impact of National Pump's fleet being added to the volume calculation. Our inflation on the fleet was a headwind. It was $18 million, detracting from the year-over-year change. And then, the rest, we'll call it mix, other, including FX, was a positive $33 million. Within that $33 million, in addition to the volume that Pump brought along, Pump operates at a higher dollar utilization, so they had a positive impact on mix of about $28 million within the $33 million. And then, I'd also call out the effect of FX in the quarter, it was pretty significant as a headwind, about $10 million of FX detraction from our year-over-year revenue performance. The other components were a sum of a whole bunch of other mix in that [ph] in the year-over-year performance. 
So those were the key drivers of our revenue performance in the quarter for rental revenue. I'd also point out that we had a very robust used equipment sales result for the quarter. Used was up 16% over last year. And as importantly, the margin was also very good, 48.7% adjusted gross margin on our used equipment sales in the quarter, certainly helped by our continued focus on driving as much as we can through our retail channel, along with the overall market price environment continues to be pretty solid in the fourth quarter. We also just touched on and had a very good new equipment sales quarter with robust growth in new equipment. 
On profitability, I'll bridge the EBITDA performance year-over-year for us. We had a company record for fourth quarter of $775 million of adjusted EBITDA. And likewise, it was a company record 49.6% margin in the quarter. So that was $124 million of increase in adjusted EBITDA. And 100 basis point improvement in our margin over fourth quarter of '13. 
Here are the components of the $124 million year-over-year improvement. The rental rate improvement that I mentioned earlier for revenue drops through the EBITDA at $39 million. That's just using a 95% flow-through on the rental rate revenue dollars. Volume contributed $74 million worth of year-over-year adjusted EBITDA. And then, we had a couple of other positives here. Ancillary and re-rent I mentioned, along with some other small pieces, contributed about $16 million. Used equipment sales, I mentioned the improvement in volume and margin there, that contributed about $14 million of improvement. And then, pump, the CAT class of pumps, because of their mix, contributed about $15 million worth of positive mix impact. Working against those positives, we had fleet inflation. That was about an $11 million headwind. Additional incentive comp, we had very strong incentive comp year and quarter, and our adjustment to the incentive comp there cost us about $10 million over the prior year. Bad debt expense cost us about $8 million. We had a strong bad debt expense result in fourth quarter of '13. We had more normalized result in '14 along with a larger AR balance. So those were the drivers there for that $8 million. Merit increases were about $6 million and all other was the remaining $1 million. So those are the components of our adjusted EBITDA change for year-over-year. If you look down at EPS, we had an adjusted EPS of $2.19 for the quarter, up very nicely from $1.59 the prior year. So all in all, a very, very strong profit picture for the quarter, as Mike mentioned.
Real quickly on cash flow. We had great free cash flow performance in the quarter as well. $557 million of free cash flow the way we calculate it, but I'll remind everyone that, that includes merger-related cash payments of about $17 million in the quarter. So the way we look at free cash flow in the quarter -- excuse me, this is full year, full year. The way we look at free cash flow for the full year is a $574 million result. The real driver there, and it did come in stronger than we expected, the real driver was better EBITDA performance, along with really, really strong collections. We've mentioned that before but our AR collections have been coming in very strong for the last number of months now and that was a big part of the betterment there in free cash flow.
Just real briefly to touch on our share repurchase program. We have been repurchasing shares. We mentioned that we bought back about $102 million of shares under the new $750 million authorization in the month of December. We added to that in the month of January. To date, in January, we spent extra $125 million. So we are now at $227 million of repurchases against that $750 million repurchase authorization. So that's the way [indiscernible] for share repurchase.
Also as Mike mentioned, I'll just reiterate, we had very nice improvement in our return on invested capital, 8.8% for the full year and that's 130 basis point improvement over the prior year with the fourth quarter sequentially improving by 40 basis points. So we feel very good about the return direction that we have the company pointed at.
Now let's talk about oil. As Michael mentioned, we've done a lot of work assessing possible impacts from low oil prices. And we've done it in a variety of different ways. We keep coming up with the same conclusion, which is that we think any reasonable expectation for impact could -- is manageable. Here's one way that we've taken a look at it and we think will resonate with folks. If we look at every branch in our company that has oil and gas revenue, we decided that the best way to look at this was to model that oil and gas revenue taking a significant hit. So in this case, we said, any branch that had oil and gas revenue, upstream oil and gas revenue, the upstream portion of their revenue stream, let's assume it takes a 35% hit, in addition, for any branch that has more than a de minimis amount of oil and gas revenue, upstream oil and gas revenue, let's also assume that everything else, all of their other revenue take a 15% hit, so they get hit 35% in oil and gas, upstream, they get hit 15% for everything else, if you do that and add it up across our company, the aggregate amount of fleet that would be freed up by those kinds of impacts would total about $400 million of average annual fleet. So $400 million relative to an $8 billion plus fleet, you could say, hey, let's dismiss that, that's not significant, but we don't think about it that way. $400 million is certainly a good amount of fleet to move around. Then we further ask ourselves, what could it mean financially? And we made some assumptions. So the $400 million is the average annual fleet. Will that kind of an impact happen over the full year? We said, no. Let's just evaluate having that impact build over the year and say it's fully in effect at the second half. So the second half is really where that hit would apply. So that $400 million annual impact, really, in calendar 2015 would only have the effect of about $200 million on a full year basis. We asked ourselves, how much of that kind of a downside could we absorb, could we mitigate? And while many of us could argue that we could absorb all of that kind of a hit, we decided to be conservative in our downside analysis and assumed we could only mitigate half that. So the $200 million annual rate, we cut down to about $100 million annual impact that represented real exposure to our company. How much is that $100 million fleet worth? We assumed a dollar utilization on that, that was very high relative to the rest of our company. We used 60% in our analysis. So 60% is at least 5 percentage points higher than the dollar utilizations that we reasonably could expect in the second half for even the highest performing regions in our company. So 60% on that $100 million annual impact gives you a $60 million revenue impact and if we're to flow that through at 60% EBITDA, it's about a $36 million EBITDA impact.
So when you look at it in that light, it doesn't scare you, right? It's not the end of the world to say there's $36 million hole we've got to figure out a way to fill. And as we said, we think that the options are fairly conservative. The good news, as Mike mentioned in his comments, is that we have assessed that there is going to be robust demand in other areas outside of oil and gas and other product types that we think can help address even if this, what we believe, severe downside plays out. So that's the way we're thinking about the risk from oil and gas. And if you add the $36 million impact that we just walked through to, or subtract that from what we expect for the full year, we still feel like we can deliver the range of adjusted EBITDA that we've given in our guidance.
Speaking of our guidance for 2015, just to reiterate the key points you've already seen, we expect total revenue in the range of $6 billion to $6.2 billion. Within that rental revenue will be driven by rates at about 3.5% for the year and time utilization of about 69%, over 20 basis point improvement over last year. The adjusted EBITDA range of $295 million to $305 million, again, we feel is a range that represents the most likely outcome for the year. We do expect to spend about $1.7 billion of gross rental CapEx and have that net down to about $1.2 billion for the year. And free cash flow will be a very robust result for us this year. Somewhere between $725 million and $775 million is what we expect. Obviously, that's significantly higher than the about $600 million number that we guided to you back in our Investor Day in December. And it really reflects the reactment of bonus depreciation for calendar '14 that Congress passed and President Obama signed just recently. So put it altogether and it looks like a very robust year for us. We wouldn't say that if we didn't believe that and believe that we have the ability to manage to that oil and gas certainly is an exposure for us. But it's an opportunity as well. And we're going to look to take advantage of the opportunities that it presents as we always have. And if we can do that, we feel like we'll be having a good conversation at this time next year.
So with that, that ends our prepared comments. And we can open up the call for questions and answers. Operator?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Ted Grace from Susquehanna.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Ted Grace from Susquehanna.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was hoping to ask on 2015 margins, I know you give revenue guidance, you give EBITDA guidance and so we can back in to kind of what's implied on both the margin and an incremental basis. But Bill, maybe if you could walk through qualitatively, some of t
componenttext: I was hoping to ask on 2015 margins, I know you give revenue guidance, you give EBITDA guidance and so we can back in to kind of what's implied on both the margin and an incremental basis. But Bill, maybe if you could walk through qualitatively, some of the key headwinds or tailwinds we should just think about influencing where we might come out on that range. So things like mix, fuel costs, incentive comp, lean inflation, just to help kind of give us some guideposts?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So I'll start, but certainly, Mike and Matt, please chime in. As we think about top line, a couple of things that swirl in the background in our thinking, obviously, walk through our oil and gas risk assessment but the question is did we get it, rig
componenttext: Sure. So I'll start, but certainly, Mike and Matt, please chime in. As we think about top line, a couple of things that swirl in the background in our thinking, obviously, walk through our oil and gas risk assessment but the question is did we get it, right? Could it be worse than that? Conversely, could it be better than that? So those are the things that surround oil and gas performance that may buy us some -- may buy us the revenue one way or another. And I'll leave you to make your own judgment about how much risk you think there is. FX is another factor that we certainly needed to be aware of. The Canadian dollar has been weakening pretty consistently. Average Canadian was down last year by about 6% to 7% year, and right now, as we said, if it flatlined from where it sits right now at about $0.81 U.S., that would be another 6% or so year-over-year headwind from the currency going down. So that's a nontrivial amount of revenue that could erode. The guidance we give is total revenue. So you have to be mindful of used and new as well. And our plan for used equipment sales this year is a reduction over what we achieved in 2014. Just look at the difference between gross CapEx and net rental CapEx, we're guiding to something like $500 million of used sales proceeds that compares to $549 million this year -- or in '14. So that will be a little bit of an impact to the revenues and maybe keeps the revenue guidance from being higher than it is. And then, there are other items that, that might impact at the adjusted EBITDA line. So for example, we had a very robust incentive compensation year this year. And when we reset the incentive comp targets for 2015, our baseline plan assumes that we hit target and only payout at target. We paid out nicely above target this year. So that will impact the positive way where we might end up on the adjusted EBITDA line. And a host of other issues. You mentioned Lean. The Lean initiatives are still rolling out and building momentum. We finished the quarter, still a little bit mess under here. We finished the year at an annualized run rate of about $30 million of Lean impact. That's up from the $23 million that we reported at the end of the third quarter. So that's another factor that's playing through our expectations for 2015. So I'll start there, and again, Mike and Matt, if you guys want to add anything or if I've forgotten anything, please.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, you captured it, Bill. It's important to note the difference in used sales is really about what has reached its rental useful life in the year and we don't have as much fleet that we have to sell. So that's why we're guiding lower there. If
componenttext: Well, I think, you captured it, Bill. It's important to note the difference in used sales is really about what has reached its rental useful life in the year and we don't have as much fleet that we have to sell. So that's why we're guiding lower there. If retail opportunities go over and above that, we'll make swings but I think it's a good pace on what we want to move out to keep our fleet fresh and to the targets we set.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would only add that everything that Bill and Matt said is spot on. I think that when you look at the projections of the industry at 8% for North America is a little bit higher than what we've experienced or what they've projected in '14. So could there
componenttext: I would only add that everything that Bill and Matt said is spot on. I think that when you look at the projections of the industry at 8% for North America is a little bit higher than what we've experienced or what they've projected in '14. So could there be some on rate, could there be opportunities? Could be. We don't know. Too early. We somewhat tempered it as we blend to the oil. But that could be an upside for us going forward.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: One other point to add is I know where you're going, right? You're looking at the midpoints of revenue and EBITDA and say, hey, flow-through there comes out at a pretty high level, 68% plus. That's an artifact of the fact that we're using ranges and the f
componenttext: One other point to add is I know where you're going, right? You're looking at the midpoints of revenue and EBITDA and say, hey, flow-through there comes out at a pretty high level, 68% plus. That's an artifact of the fact that we're using ranges and the fact that the flow-through calculation is very sensitive. If we were at point blank, we would still say that we think about flow-through for 2015 being something like 60% would [indiscernible] toward the upside because of the net effect of all of the things that I mentioned earlier. So if you're modeling, I'd say get your revenue where you wanted, use 60% and then maybe put your thumb on scale a little bit higher to reflect some of the net benefits that we expect to accrue over the course of the year.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: That super helpful. The only follow-up I have is any willingness to quantify kind of what Lean expectations are? I know you exited a run rate of 30, you're targeting $100 million-plus through the program over a few years but any chance you could just cali
componenttext: That super helpful. The only follow-up I have is any willingness to quantify kind of what Lean expectations are? I know you exited a run rate of 30, you're targeting $100 million-plus through the program over a few years but any chance you could just calibrate us on what that tailwind will might look like this year?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, you could do the trends. This is Matt. You could do that trends. I mean, we'd expect it to follow that trend, right? So we've set external target -- I mean, internal targets above that for '15. We've even -- we've put even extra emphasis on it this
componenttext: Well, you could do the trends. This is Matt. You could do that trends. I mean, we'd expect it to follow that trend, right? So we've set external target -- I mean, internal targets above that for '15. We've even -- we've put even extra emphasis on it this year but I feel very comfortable that we'll keep it steady paced towards that $100 million by the end of '16.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Justin Jordan from Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Justin Jordan from Jefferies.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just want to talk about the nice problem of having extra free cash flow and what that might mean in terms of changes or your -- the board's thinking about capital allocation in calendar '15? Because obviously, relative to the guidance you gave on Decemb
componenttext: I just want to talk about the nice problem of having extra free cash flow and what that might mean in terms of changes or your -- the board's thinking about capital allocation in calendar '15? Because obviously, relative to the guidance you gave on December 4, essentially, you've increased free cash flow guidance by 25% overnight. Now I appreciate there's a tax implication here that not really that much a percentage gain. But is that changing how you think about potential specialty M&A? Is that changing how you think about deleveraging or potentially changing how you think about the amount of stock repurchasing you might do in '15?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Did you want to give a bit more color than that?
componenttext: Did you want to give a bit more color than that?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, you get one question. I think, what I would say on M&A is we're always looking at M&A opportunities and I'm flipping but I don't think it changes how we think about M&A. If we found the right M&A opportunity, then we would go ahead and do that whether
componenttext: No, you get one question. I think, what I would say on M&A is we're always looking at M&A opportunities and I'm flipping but I don't think it changes how we think about M&A. If we found the right M&A opportunity, then we would go ahead and do that whether we were at $600 million or $700 million or $775 million of free cash flow. So M&A wouldn't change. I think, it is fair to say that as we look at the share repurchase program, if you got more cash flow and you want to pass the leverage and we've already said we expect to be toward the low end of the leverage range that we want to operate in by the end of this year, we've called $2.6 billion as the leverage ratio you expect before the increase in free cash flow. So I think we would be more inclined to say, okay, let's not go crazy and go below the $2.5 billion kind of leverage ratio this year now that we've got more cash flow coming in. So that may change how we think about the timing of the share repurchase program. And I think that's a sensible way to think about it. So that's all still to be discussed. And certainly, we'll talk about it more as we make more decisions. But I'd say, M&A doesn't change, but everything else we kind of put in, in the mix and say, okay, we've got an extra $100 million, what do you want to do with it and we'll make that call.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Seth Weber from RBC Capital.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Seth Weber from RBC Capital.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to talk about your CapEx commentary, specifically the comments around flexibility around CapEx. And you kept the $1.7 billion gross number for the year. Should we think about cadence this year being similar to how it's been in the prior year, so
componenttext: I wanted to talk about your CapEx commentary, specifically the comments around flexibility around CapEx. And you kept the $1.7 billion gross number for the year. Should we think about cadence this year being similar to how it's been in the prior year, so 60% to 65% in the first half? Or do you hold back some of the spending to wait and see how the markets evolve? That's my first question. And then, kind of as an add-on to that, I mean, it sounds like your specialty as a percentage of your growth capital is down. I think last year was something like, I don't know, 270, 280, something like that, now it's 170, I think you said. Is that reduction primarily focused on the pump business? Or how should we think about your cap -- growth capital going towards the specialty category?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Seth. So I'll answer both questions. The first, as far as the cadence, if we plan on to being similar to this year, you know that we have really strong flexibility as far as we don't need to make a decision of we're going to ship until literally a w
componenttext: Sure, Seth. So I'll answer both questions. The first, as far as the cadence, if we plan on to being similar to this year, you know that we have really strong flexibility as far as we don't need to make a decision of we're going to ship until literally a week before it's going to ship. So the second quarter, by April, I think, we'll get a very good feel if the second quarter is going to be more or less and it will all be demand-driven. The first quarter was light already, which is good for us, and right now, we restrict the inflow of CapEx obviously in the market set we think may have a little bit of softening in demand in the back half of the year. So I really think we'll get a better picture on how much we adjust for more norm and I would call last year's cadence a new norm, depending on what the demand is and where we're getting our returns and where our customers need our services. So that's how we feel about the cadence. As far as the specialty, we spent -- we plan on spending over 30% of our growth capital on specialty. You're talking about more of a gross number when you're referring to last year's number and a lot of that was, I would say, re-fleeting our pump, right? So we need that acquisition to grow. And fleeting up the many cold starts that we've done in our other specialty segments, specifically power, even the year before, so they were now ready to absorb scale. So we really pushed a lot into the cold starts over the last couple of years. And we'll do some more cold starts this year but not at the scale that we did over the past 2 years.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Sorry, Matt. So my -- was my math incorrect? I thought your specialty last year represented like half of the growth capital or something like that?
componenttext: Okay. Sorry, Matt. So my -- was my math incorrect? I thought your specialty last year represented like half of the growth capital or something like that?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Mike. You're close to that number. To Matt's point, if you go back to '13, we had a significant amount of our cold starts stuck that we're in, in the later part of the fourth quarter that a lot of that CapEx ran into 2014 and then, the cold starts
componenttext: This is Mike. You're close to that number. To Matt's point, if you go back to '13, we had a significant amount of our cold starts stuck that we're in, in the later part of the fourth quarter that a lot of that CapEx ran into 2014 and then, the cold starts we had through the course of the year and then freeing all of those as we went through the year. So in total numbers, it's down, you're right, but it hasn't changed our view on specialty. We do reserve the right on pump to understand what impact upstream could or could not have as we go through our cross-sell opportunities. And we -- as I mentioned, we will do cold starts with pump to broaden their reach and that was 1 of the key aspects of the acquisition was making sure that, if you recall, 6% of their business was only in our commercial and industrial space. So we see that as a significant opportunity. So it's kind of more of a tempered look, take a look at it. And as I also mentioned, if there's a need for more growth capital, we've got it and we'll do it. The flexibility is built into our model.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And Matt, have you seen anything -- can you make any comments on used equipment pricing because I think that's something that people are increasingly nervous about?
componenttext: Okay. And Matt, have you seen anything -- can you make any comments on used equipment pricing because I think that's something that people are increasingly nervous about?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, other than that, [indiscernible] so we enjoyed a real robust fourth quarter from a volume a little bit more than we even expected in the month of December and with margins holding flat. So -- and flat at a very high-level. So we're seeing still a ro
componenttext: Well, other than that, [indiscernible] so we enjoyed a real robust fourth quarter from a volume a little bit more than we even expected in the month of December and with margins holding flat. So -- and flat at a very high-level. So we're seeing still a robust used equipment market.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of David Raso from Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of David Raso from Evercore ISI.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: On the oil downside scenario, I was just curious, what percent of your entire fleet is captured and what you're considering at risk territories? And then, secondarily, just trying to think through rental rates in that scenario, just trying to capture if y
componenttext: On the oil downside scenario, I was just curious, what percent of your entire fleet is captured and what you're considering at risk territories? And then, secondarily, just trying to think through rental rates in that scenario, just trying to capture if you feel there's any potential knock-on effect to rates in territories where other equipment might be going into or essentially just given the rate pressure you may see in those weaker energy-sensitive markets?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I'll tackle the rate 1 first. The 3.5 -- about 3.5 guidance that we gave is lower than where we were thinking about rate, call it a month ago or 2 months ago. And so in that sense, we have included some conservatism to reflect the fact that rate could
componenttext: So I'll tackle the rate 1 first. The 3.5 -- about 3.5 guidance that we gave is lower than where we were thinking about rate, call it a month ago or 2 months ago. And so in that sense, we have included some conservatism to reflect the fact that rate could be pressured as that oil and gas dynamic plays out. And yet, we still think 3.5. Could it be worse than that? Obviously, it could. But again, we think we've got opportunities to respond and manage it down. I don't remember off the top of my head the first question of what the percent of the fleet...

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, if you just do the math right, so we said a 35% knock-on -- I mean, the 35% upstream would net in, in about $400 million. So it's over $1 billion. I'd say, it's somewhere in $1 billion or $1.2 billion, I don't have the number right handy in front of
componenttext: Well, if you just do the math right, so we said a 35% knock-on -- I mean, the 35% upstream would net in, in about $400 million. So it's over $1 billion. I'd say, it's somewhere in $1 billion or $1.2 billion, I don't have the number right handy in front of me but I think that the last [indiscernible] it's probably $1.2 billion of fleet that we think will be impacted and those are markets that have oil and gas upstream business today.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. I mean, I may be oversimplifying it. Not everything in these states are driven by energy but I'm just thinking about 29% of your branches, I know branches aren't the same, I know that, but just going through the data we have, 29% of branches are in
componenttext: Okay. I mean, I may be oversimplifying it. Not everything in these states are driven by energy but I'm just thinking about 29% of your branches, I know branches aren't the same, I know that, but just going through the data we have, 29% of branches are in what I'd consider in somewhat energy-sensitive states and the oil sands. And in your analysis, you're saying kind of roughly half of that's at risk, I guess, right? Because $1.2 billion of the $8.44 billion of fleet is about 14%, is that the right way to think of it roughly? Half of the branches in those states in oil sands is sort of at risk? I'm just trying to understand the analysis.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's hard to do the analysis based on branches and states and get anything useful in our opinion. That's why we went to the individual location and tried to reason from what business they have that's exposed right here and now. So we didn't do it to
componenttext: Yes, it's hard to do the analysis based on branches and states and get anything useful in our opinion. That's why we went to the individual location and tried to reason from what business they have that's exposed right here and now. So we didn't do it to go to great levels of detail on how many branches or in which states. We have that. I don't know that it's something we want to go through in great detail. But just the $400 million impact, I think, really does capture a pretty good view of what the exposure might be. But if you don't believe it, okay, make it a $500 million impact, let's say we're off by 25%, or even a $600 million impact and say we're off by 50%. The end result doesn't change dramatically, right? It's still a $35 million, $40 million, $45 million to $50 million kind of risk even with conservative assumptions about how far down it goes and how much we can mitigate. I like our chances with that kind of risk scenario.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. No, I appreciate it. I think the issue is, is there more territory at risk than solely branches that happen to have upstream oil and gas in their region? I mean, it's obviously just debate right now about contagion beyond just those direct areas. An
componenttext: Sure. No, I appreciate it. I think the issue is, is there more territory at risk than solely branches that happen to have upstream oil and gas in their region? I mean, it's obviously just debate right now about contagion beyond just those direct areas. And also on the rates, I mean, you've done a great job this cycle on saying we're not going to throw capital up the fleet just to grow. We're going to focus on better returns. Should I expect, if I'm thinking maybe a little more cautiously about the impact and broader contagion, you're going to hold rate before you try to hold utilization? I mean, if I had to model from some downside sensitivity, should I be taking it more down on utilization, you'd argue? Or taking down on the rate? I'm just trying to get a feel for philosophically if things got weaker than you're forecasting.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, all right. I'm sorry, Matt, I'll let you...
componenttext: Yes, all right. I'm sorry, Matt, I'll let you...

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, it will depend, right, on what the demand is and what we're seeing but I would say that we're going to have utilization at the level that it needs to be at because we can do -- we can manage that. We can manage how much fleet we put into market and ho
componenttext: No, it will depend, right, on what the demand is and what we're seeing but I would say that we're going to have utilization at the level that it needs to be at because we can do -- we can manage that. We can manage how much fleet we put into market and how much fleet we remove out of a market. So I think we'll be very diligent on those rate and time but time is much more easily manageable. And I think, as Bill stated, we built in a little conservatism on the rate because moving a fleet from higher rate areas and your growth fleet into areas that aren't your top 10% is going to have some knock, whether it's 0.25, 0.50, I don't think we really know yet but I think we've captured it in our guidance.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess, I'll take that then if you feel that the utilization is coming under some pressure. While you want to hold rate, you might play with it a bit, but the key is you also have the outlet valve of, well, I'm just going to sell fleet. I mean, I guess t
componenttext: I guess, I'll take that then if you feel that the utilization is coming under some pressure. While you want to hold rate, you might play with it a bit, but the key is you also have the outlet valve of, well, I'm just going to sell fleet. I mean, I guess that's the idea of used. If prices hold up, you can manage utilization also by just simply shutting some fleet and I think that's the key issue of used prices, if they hold up, you can do that relatively profitably but that's obviously part of the debate. So we should think of let's just try to move fleet, you also can tap the retail market the best you can on sell and used.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thank you, David.
componenttext: Yes. Thank you, David.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, David.
componenttext: Thanks, David.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Joe Box from KeyBanc Capital.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Joe Box from KeyBanc Capital.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I've got a question on your construction pipeline on Slide 13. And I just want to tie that together maybe with your methodology on guidance. So how should we be thinking about $370 billion pipeline and how you incorporate that into your guidance? And then
componenttext: I've got a question on your construction pipeline on Slide 13. And I just want to tie that together maybe with your methodology on guidance. So how should we be thinking about $370 billion pipeline and how you incorporate that into your guidance? And then, maybe just to take it 1 step further, what are your guys in the ground telling for some of these energy-sensitive projects that have already started or maybe are just a few months away from breaking ground? Are they concerned about this? Are they thinking everything kind of moves forward as planned?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So this is Matt, Joe. So we do have some key account managers that specifically just call on oil and gas. So obviously, they're hearing the most noise about whether it's future concerns or some job cancellations. But even in that space, the pipeline was s
componenttext: So this is Matt, Joe. So we do have some key account managers that specifically just call on oil and gas. So obviously, they're hearing the most noise about whether it's future concerns or some job cancellations. But even in that space, the pipeline was so robust that, individually, they may have opportunity. I think, more importantly, the other 90% of our key account managers are extremely encouraged because we've always sent the fleet to the highest return opportunity and oil and gas was pretty hot for a while. You could argue, we may have underserved a lot of other opportunity that will give us very good returns and a little bit more geographically dispersed. So I think that what we're hearing on the ground is encouragement and opportunity in markets like the West Coast, even the Northwest or Southeast, the mid-Atlantic, where you could see the map that we have on the investor deck on, I think, it was Slide 14, where you see there's some real big opportunities. So that's what we're hearing, that's why we feel very strong about our guidance, our customers have the demand and our boots on the ground are seeing them.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Scott Schneeberger from Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Scott Schneeberger from Oppenheimer.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll follow up on Joe's question. On Slide 14, that is, it's a nice add, it says construction overall, is that non-res construction? Could you specify? And then, could you speak to the end markets in those 6 or 7 states where you see the double digit grow
componenttext: I'll follow up on Joe's question. On Slide 14, that is, it's a nice add, it says construction overall, is that non-res construction? Could you specify? And then, could you speak to the end markets in those 6 or 7 states where you see the double digit growth?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So would you, Seth (sic) [Scott], want to know about the verticals or where the opportunities are in those states or just the specific states?
componenttext: So would you, Seth (sic) [Scott], want to know about the verticals or where the opportunities are in those states or just the specific states?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, I could see the states on Slide 14, the vertical opportunities in those states and what type of construction specifically?
componenttext: No, I could see the states on Slide 14, the vertical opportunities in those states and what type of construction specifically?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So, I think, Mike covered a little bit of it in his opening remarks. When I say it's broad, it's broad. I mean, there are multiple states, multiple planned expansions, manufacturing. I'd say the single largest vertical would probably be chemical. Chemical
componenttext: So, I think, Mike covered a little bit of it in his opening remarks. When I say it's broad, it's broad. I mean, there are multiple states, multiple planned expansions, manufacturing. I'd say the single largest vertical would probably be chemical. Chemical expenses have shown robust growth. Even the State of Texas, right? We talked a lot about the contagion impact in Texas. We have a very large portion of our business in Texas that's chemical-related. And that's forecasted to be 26% growth in Texas. So we think that there's many verticals that are positive in places that we're going to serve in 2015. And it is that broad-based, which is why I'm not -- I mean, chemical stands out at just how much growth there is, which is why I'm not honing in on the other vertical because it's very broad.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just following up on that, how much is that is forecast and how much of that do you fill is in hand at this point of the year?
componenttext: Okay. And just following up on that, how much is that is forecast and how much of that do you fill is in hand at this point of the year?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I don't have the putt in place in front of me right now but you could think about it as the pipeline through the seasons of the year. And certainly, there's less start right now although our timing remain very strong. I would say, by mid-summer, you're
componenttext: So I don't have the putt in place in front of me right now but you could think about it as the pipeline through the seasons of the year. And certainly, there's less start right now although our timing remain very strong. I would say, by mid-summer, you're going to see at least half of that pipeline materialize in rental opportunity. So -- and then, it's just a matter of how quick things move from that and that's standard with the construction cycle that we've been experiencing throughout my career.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Joe O'Dea from Vertical Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Joe O'Dea from Vertical Research.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: A question just on the potential risk of accelerated fleet growth across the industry with what is a pretty strong backdrop and really your ability to monitor what your competitors are doing and if there's any particular competitor segment, whether that's
componenttext: A question just on the potential risk of accelerated fleet growth across the industry with what is a pretty strong backdrop and really your ability to monitor what your competitors are doing and if there's any particular competitor segment, whether that's by region or size of competitor, that you think would be the largest risk to maybe over-accelerating fleet growth and adding some rental rate price pressure?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So yes, I'll start. The ability to monitor is pretty good, right? We're everywhere and we touch, I won't say customer, but a lot of the market. And so we've got realtime intelligence on what our competitors are doing. And we feel we have the ability to re
componenttext: So yes, I'll start. The ability to monitor is pretty good, right? We're everywhere and we touch, I won't say customer, but a lot of the market. And so we've got realtime intelligence on what our competitors are doing. And we feel we have the ability to respond if we think responding is appropriate and that's one of the advantages of being who we are. In terms of what competitor might be most at risk? We won't name names here. I'll leave you to make your own judgment about that. All we can say is that United Rentals is going to be very conscious about any type of decision, whether it's increase or decrease and it's going to be driven by what we're taking in from the market.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jerry Revich from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jerry Revich from Goldman Sachs.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Can you gentlemen talk about what you're hearing from your refining customers? I think that was 1 of RSC's bigger industrial end markets. If I remember their disclosures, right, we've seen them cut back in CapEx but I think the equipment's been more on th
componenttext: Can you gentlemen talk about what you're hearing from your refining customers? I think that was 1 of RSC's bigger industrial end markets. If I remember their disclosures, right, we've seen them cut back in CapEx but I think the equipment's been more on the maintenance side of everyday type work, is that right? Can you just give us an update for that end market?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Certainly. So we have heard of some CapEx cutbacks and I would say probably more severe in the oil sands than anywhere else. And there have been a couple of projects in the Gulf that have canceled, but I would say overall, that pipeline is still robust, a
componenttext: Certainly. So we have heard of some CapEx cutbacks and I would say probably more severe in the oil sands than anywhere else. And there have been a couple of projects in the Gulf that have canceled, but I would say overall, that pipeline is still robust, and you're accurate, the large amount of on-site of relationships that we acquired during the merger with RSC really, really gives us a strong base to work from. We're not seeing any slowdown of that maintenance at all. As a matter of fact, our industrial region is showing the highest time utilization we have in the company right now and the highest year-over-year growth. And they're primarily on-site and what I would call downstream oil and gas and chemical plants and we're just seeing real strong growth there and I don't think that maintenance was going to take a hit here. I think, it's mostly capital spend, which if we really wanted to be, you could say there's an opportunity in there for us to get more penetration as capital continues to get cut from some of the end markets.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was just going to say also on our slide, our customer confidence index, reaching out, we only -- of the 170 key accounts that we reached out to, only 1% saw a slower growth in 2015. We spend an awful lot of time in preparation for this call reaching out
componenttext: I was just going to say also on our slide, our customer confidence index, reaching out, we only -- of the 170 key accounts that we reached out to, only 1% saw a slower growth in 2015. We spend an awful lot of time in preparation for this call reaching out to our customers, reaching out to our employees. I know more about oil in the last 2 weeks than my 35 years in the industry. And I would tell you that we haven't seen any significant impact talking to our customer's steel erectors. Steel erectors, when you take a look at their book of business and bidding, not 1 of the projects I saw had any relationship to oil at all. And they would say it's a record opportunity and year for them coming up on their bidding requirements. So that along with -- Jerry, the feedback that we're getting from ARA and Global Insight, which by the way, has been inside this industry for close to 7 years, maybe longer, working with our industry, refining the nuances of their model on how this industry reacts to things. When they come out with 8%, we take that to heart and that's not soft, that's not easy, and we think that, that's a good indication of where our industry is going.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Matt, just a clarification, if you don't mind. The cancellations that you mentioned, was that ground-up projects that you're referring to or is that just brownfield type work?
componenttext: And Matt, just a clarification, if you don't mind. The cancellations that you mentioned, was that ground-up projects that you're referring to or is that just brownfield type work?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ground-up projects. So there were a couple of plans. I mean, the pipeline that we went through in our fourth quarter QBRs with our regions, we saw more projects start with $1 billion than I've seen in the last couple of years combined. And candidly, half
componenttext: Ground-up projects. So there were a couple of plans. I mean, the pipeline that we went through in our fourth quarter QBRs with our regions, we saw more projects start with $1 billion than I've seen in the last couple of years combined. And candidly, half of those projects cut, I think, a more robust pipeline than we had over the past few years as far as large projects. And we have seen maybe 10% of those get cut off the table right now because of the concerns that everybody has. So they'll hold back on some of these new construction, new capital projects but it's -- I still feel the pipeline, as Mike stated and we've all stated, very robust and the Global Insight survey just kind of supports what we're hearing from our customers and from our boots on the ground.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Steven Fisher from UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Steven Fisher from UBS.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: How would you guys describe your expectations for Canada overall in 2015 relative to the U.S. I know you just mentioned some oil sands, a weakness, but just Canada overall? And then, how easy is it to reallocate equipment from Canada to the U.S.? Or would
componenttext: How would you guys describe your expectations for Canada overall in 2015 relative to the U.S. I know you just mentioned some oil sands, a weakness, but just Canada overall? And then, how easy is it to reallocate equipment from Canada to the U.S.? Or would you more envision reallocating amongst the provinces?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll start and I'll ask Matt to tie in. But as part of the overall review with ARA, they're looking at a little over 3% growth for all of Canada. That combines with the 8.5% they're projecting for the U.S. would give them just around 8%, 8.1% growth for N
componenttext: I'll start and I'll ask Matt to tie in. But as part of the overall review with ARA, they're looking at a little over 3% growth for all of Canada. That combines with the 8.5% they're projecting for the U.S. would give them just around 8%, 8.1% growth for North America. I actually think that Eastern Canada, which by the way has been down for the last several years, we'll see some activity there and come forward. The only headwind we would have, as Bill mentioned, is the currency exchange from a revenue, but on a constant dollars, we would expect that to grow. So we see that -- the Canadian market grow and probably less growth on Western Canada than we've experienced in the past.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would agree, Mike. We'll just stay in same currency, right, because that's how I would manage those businesses and judge them. We will see growth in both of those, in both Western and Eastern Canada regions next year. And like all of our regions, we do
componenttext: I would agree, Mike. We'll just stay in same currency, right, because that's how I would manage those businesses and judge them. We will see growth in both of those, in both Western and Eastern Canada regions next year. And like all of our regions, we do 0 growth CapEx budgets so they're going to have to earn their growth as they stack rank against their peers and they fared pretty well in the past and I expect them to fare pretty well in the future, specifically Western Canada.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And in terms of reallocating equipment between Canada and the U.S., is that something you would envision doing and how easy is that?
componenttext: And in terms of reallocating equipment between Canada and the U.S., is that something you would envision doing and how easy is that?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think, because we have -- when you think about the $1.7 billion of new capital that we spend, that's 20% of a late $24 billion base, if we start with this year's base. We've historically been able to reship geographically by utilizing equipment sales in
componenttext: I think, because we have -- when you think about the $1.7 billion of new capital that we spend, that's 20% of a late $24 billion base, if we start with this year's base. We've historically been able to reship geographically by utilizing equipment sales in either not replacing in that market, not putting growth capital in that market. So we've been able to geographically remix through that. If we had to put trucks on their fleet, we'd do that and there are some instances [indiscernible] Western Canada, but if it was really dropping, that's not something that we would do. The cost costs are minimal compared to the opportunity you'd have by reallocating. But right now, they're running high time utilization and we're just going to manage the influx in the energy, oil and gas markets first. And I think that will prevent them from having to move fleet but we can react very quickly, whether it's in Canada or somewhere else to move fleet.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our final question, due to time constraints, comes from the line of Nicole DeBlase from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And our final question, due to time constraints, comes from the line of Nicole DeBlase from Morgan Stanley.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So just -- most of mine have been answered, but just 1 on utilization. So I was kind of surprised to see that you're for flattish utilization in '15. Is that also conservatism around oil and gas risk or are we kind of at the high watermark for utilization
componenttext: So just -- most of mine have been answered, but just 1 on utilization. So I was kind of surprised to see that you're for flattish utilization in '15. Is that also conservatism around oil and gas risk or are we kind of at the high watermark for utilization this cycle?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't say we're at the high watermark. We still feel we've got opportunities to continue to drive utilization. We've talked in the past of all 3 of us probably remain that we can get in the 70s if the market holds and if we do the things that we thin
componenttext: I wouldn't say we're at the high watermark. We still feel we've got opportunities to continue to drive utilization. We've talked in the past of all 3 of us probably remain that we can get in the 70s if the market holds and if we do the things that we think we can do. The 69% would be up 20 basis points so I guess you could call that flat if you like. But that is tempered somewhat like the rate discussion is tempered somewhat by our concern about oil and gas and about while we think we can mitigate, we don't know that we will be able to mitigate 100% of any oil and gas often. And so we backed off a little a bit from where we were a month or 2 ago in our talk about 2015, but we still think that's a very robust performance on utilization. And Matt's comments earlier, utilization is something that we certainly have lots of levers that we can use, right? If it's falling down, you can sell more or you can buy less and threaten the business you do have on our fleet. We think that we can pull all the appropriate levers and deliver at about 69%, and we think that's a step on the way towards better utilization over the next several years.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's really helpful. And then, just for my follow-up, thinking about 1Q as far as what you guys have seen so far quarter-to-date, should we expect to see like normal seasonality this quarter?
componenttext: Okay. That's really helpful. And then, just for my follow-up, thinking about 1Q as far as what you guys have seen so far quarter-to-date, should we expect to see like normal seasonality this quarter?

componenttext: Yes, I would say so. We're experiencing very similar metrics than we did to last year when you look at rate and time utilization maybe up a hair in time for a couple of weeks but it's early. I think, it will fall right in line with our usual cadence.
