headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the United Rentals First Quarter 2015 Investor Conference Call. Please be advised that is call is being recorded.Before we begin, note that the company's press release, comments made on today's call and responses to your que
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the United Rentals First Quarter 2015 Investor Conference Call. Please be advised that is call is being recorded.
Before we begin, note that the company's press release, comments made on today's call and responses to your questions contain forward-looking statements. The company's business and operations are subject to a variety of risks and uncertainties, many of which are beyond its control, and consequently, actual results may differ materially from those projected.
A summary of these uncertainties is included in the Safe Harbor statement contained in the company's earnings release. For a more complete description of these and other possible risks, please refer to the company's annual report on Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2014, as well as to subsequent filings with the SEC. You can access these filings on the company's website at www.ur.com.
Please note that United Rentals has no obligation and makes no commitment to update or publicly release any revisions to forward-looking statements in order to reflect new information or subsequent events, circumstances or changes in expectation. You should also note that the company's earnings release, investor presentation and today's call include references to free cash flow, adjusted EPS, EBITDA and adjusted EBITDA, each of which is a non-GAAP term.
Speaking today for United Rentals is Michael Kneeland, Chief Executive Officer; William Plummer, Chief Financial Officer; and Matt Flannery, Chief Operating Officer.
I will now turn the call over to Mr. Kneeland. Mr. Kneeland, you may begin.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, operator, and good morning, everyone and welcome. Thank you for joining us on today's call. Today we'll talk about how we're managing the business in light of our expectations for 2015 with almost 4 months of the year behind us, we've been able to
componenttext:
Thanks, operator, and good morning, everyone and welcome. Thank you for joining us on today's call. Today we'll talk about how we're managing the business in light of our expectations for 2015 with almost 4 months of the year behind us, we've been able to draw conclusions on how this year is shaping up and we'll talk more about that in a minute and then Bill will cover the results followed by your questions.
So let's begin with the numbers you saw last night. We had a solid start to the year. Our revenue, EBITDA and return on invested capital are all first quarter records. And that's a credit to our employees. Our rental revenue increased 12% year-over-year based in part on an 8% increase in volume. We generated $602 million of adjusted EBITDA at a 46% margin.
Our return on invested capital improved to 9% and our free cash flow for the quarter was $450 million, more than 60% higher than a year ago. We also reported record adjusted EPS of $1.34 for the quarter.
Now we achieved these results despite some notable headwinds, the most significant constraint was the decline in Upstream oil and gas activity. The rapid shutdown of almost 50% of drill rigs had both a direct and knock on effect. And this was felt most strongly in our Pump operations.
The slowdown also happened earlier than expected and we now think it's likely to continue to at least the next 3 to 6 months. We still expect to mitigate the decline within our guidance for revenue and adjusted EBITDA and we'll have more opportunity to do that now during the peak seasonality.
Now given the timing of the impact, we felt it was really stick to narrow the ranges of revenue and EBITDA. Our updated revenue range is $6 billion to $6.1 billion below and adjusted EBITDA of $2.95 billion to $3 billion. And these ranges still full within our regional outlook.
Now in addition, in the first quarter, we had a negative currency impact from a relatively weaker Canadian dollar and this will likely impact our year-over-year comparisons throughout 2015. In the harsh winter slowed the pace of the projects in several regions where we dealt with historic cold and snow. Now with that one, we can safely say that's behind us. But despite these headwinds, we put a record $5.4 billion of OEC-on-Rent in the first quarter in a highly competitive marketplace.
We could leave it at that but as you know, we're not a company that shies away from looking at numbers from every angle. In the first quarter, the metrics of time utilization and rate merit for the discussion. Time utilization decreased in the quarter by 40 basis points to 64%. And to change our outlook, we're still comfortable with our full year time utilization of approximately 69%. And when we look what at branches without any meaningful exposure to Upstream oil and gas activity, time utilization was actually up 40 basis points in the quarter.
With pricing, our rate increase of 2.9% in the quarter versus last year and that was lower than expected and we're now anticipating a very competitive rate environment going into the summer months. But I know that our field management feels like I do that there are actions that we can take to get our prices up. Now coming off the quarter, we now expect our rate increase to be about 3% for the full year instead of the original regional outlook of 3.5%.
Regardless of any headwinds, we'll continue to transfer underutilized fleet to areas of higher demand where our sales force have more leverage to negotiate rates. And we'll help have even more opportunity to get the equipment on rent as we go into our seasonality as it picks up.
We're focused on achieving that optimal balance of metrics that we talked about before, that is where rate and time utilization intersect to drive returns. We see this as being absolutely essential as we continue to capitalize on the up-cycle and a large measure is within our control regardless of external developments.
Now let's turn to the marketplace starting with specialty rentals. The organic revenue growth in our specialty segment was 25% in the quarter and EBITDA was up 57%, Trench Safety and Power were particularly strong. Specialty rentals are our high margin business and help drive our fifth consecutive first quarter increase of EBITDA margin company-wide.
We'll expand all of our specialty lines this year with an addition of approximately 18 new branches. This will give us a strategic presence in new trade areas and strengthen our cross-selling abilities.
From a broader perspective, our operating environment continues to match up favorably against last year. Our sales force is reporting high level of project starts and if anything, our customers are even more optimistic than they were in December.
And this is true for our large National Accounts, as well as regional operators and local contractors. We're serving a diverse customer base that has maintained a healthy balance year-over-year going into April. Key accounts represent 65% of our base by revenue. That includes National Accounts at 46% of our base. And our local customers, which we classify as unassigned accounts, ticked up slightly to 35%.
Let's now turn to geography. On a constant currency basis, all but 1 of our regions had year-over-year growth and that 1 was nearly flat. The Mid-Atlantic, South, Midwest and Mountain West regions had a particularly strong quarter. And I want to give a nod to our industrial team, which has continued to score wins in the downstream energy sector. Energy gets a rep right now but from our perspective, we're seeing some impressive numbers.
We currently have commitments for 8 multibillion-dollar energy projects, 4 of which are underway, 2 are in the third stage and the other 2 will kick off in 2016 and 2018. All of these are 3 to 6-year projects in Texas or Louisiana.
But beyond energy, we're seeing many different sectors pick up. For example, our major infrastructure project are renovations in Ottawa and Montral, large stadium projects in Atlanta and Fort Lauderdale and renewables such as wind firms in Kansas. And I want to share something new about Texas, which is a large and diversified markets for us.
If you exclude Pump, the increase in rental revenue was in the mid-teens on a year-over-year basis. That points to a solid demand outside of Upstream oil and gas. We've always had to write up some sector related cycles but the fundamentals of our markets are very strong.
We should see broad-based growth well beyond 2015 as our customers take on more work and secular penetration adds an extra layer of demand. Most industry forecasts supports this view. 1 recent release is the consensus construction report put up by the American Institute of Architects that takes account 7 major forecasters, including Dodge and Moody's. Report concludes that construction -- Commercial Construction, which is our bread-and-butter, is forecast to remain on a strong upward trajectory, hotels, office buildings and retail are just some of the areas -- just a few of some of the areas projected to contribute to that growth.
And the institutional sector, which had a disappointing decline in 2014, appears to have bottomed out. The consensus is that institutional construction will reverse to a gain in 2015 and climb again in 2016. And that's good news for markets such as health, education and public safety.
So that gives you an idea where we see the challenges and the opportunities for 2015. And to some degree, in 2016 as well. Taking everything into consideration, we remain confident in our full year guidance of adjusted EBITDA of at least $2.95 billion on total revenue of at least $6 billion.
But we're balancing these metrics behind those numbers in light of the market dynamics, and we expect to spend $1.7 billion of gross rental CapEx this year as planned. Now in short, we show that we have the right plan, we know we have the right plan in place for 2015. And our strategy for the long-term, profitable growth remains intact.
So with that, I'll ask Bill to cover the financial results and then we'll take your questions. So over to you, Bill.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike, and good morning to everyone. We've got a lot to cover here, so I'm going to try and streamline my comments about the actuals so we can save a little time to touch on the refinancings that we did, touch on our oil and gas experience for the
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike, and good morning to everyone. We've got a lot to cover here, so I'm going to try and streamline my comments about the actuals so we can save a little time to touch on the refinancings that we did, touch on our oil and gas experience for the first quarter and also the outlook. 
Real briefly on the financials, we had a good revenue result in the quarter. Rental revenue was up by almost 12%, 11.9%, as Mike called out. That's a $119 million, $120 million improvement and the drivers were as follows: The ancillary and re-rent revenue performance for the quarter was good. We had about a $14 million year-over-year improvement from those 2 combined. The bulk of it being ancillary, pick up delivery and our RPP program, re-rent was just a little better than flat year-over-year. So that was about $14 million of the $120 million.
Within owned equipment revenue, OER, rental rate growth, you saw was 2.9%. We translate that into about a $26 million improvement over last year. On the volume front, we had 8.1% volume improvement and that translates into about $72 million of volume impact, which I'll note includes the impact of heavy Pump this year and not in the first quarter of last year. Also sprinkled throughout volume and some of the other lines is the FX impact that we experienced in the quarter. I'll summarize that at the and.
Inflation, replacement CapEx inflation, we called at about 2.1% for the quarter and that's a headwind of just under $19 million year-over-year. And then mix, all other, including some portion of FX, accounted for  $27 million year-over-year. That includes the impact again of the Pump acquisition as we talked before, Pump not only contributed to the acquisition but has a more attractive mix than the rest of the business. And so that was a significant part of that $27 million.
So those were the key components of the $120 million improvement. And I'll just call out separately if you aggregate all of the currency impact, we estimate that currency cost us about $16 million of rental revenue year-over-year. And that certainly is a significant headwind when you think about the growth that we were able to experience.
The only other revenue comment that I'll make is about used equipment sales. We had another good used equipment sales result in the quarter, $116 million. And that's up about 6% from last year. And also very importantly, a very robust 50.7 % adjusted gross margin for the quarter. And as has been the case, that was helped not only by solid pricing in the quarter. Pricing as measured by proceeds as a percent  of OEC was just under 50% in the quarter but it also was supported by our continued focus on the retail channel we get the best results, margin results there. And so selling about 61% of our used sales through retail channel was a nice support for the results.
Turning quickly to profitability. EBITDA first, adjusted EBITDA of $602.2 million was a company record for the quarter, as Mike pointed out, as was the adjusted EBITDA margin, 45.8% was a very robust margin. So that's $83 million worth of dollar improvement over last year and 170 basis points worth of margin improvement as well. 
Flow through in the quarter was strong at 60.6%. And we'll certainly touch on some of the drivers there in the year-over-year EBITDA bridge. Speaking of which, that $83 million of improvement was driven by volume. Primarily, volume was up about $51 million of the $83 million year-over-year improvement. Rental rates contributed another $24 million toward that $83 million improvement. The cat class mix, primarily from the impact of adding pump, we would call out at about $14 million of incremental improvement. And then we also had the improvement from ancillary and re-rent revenues that I called out earlier. That's about a $7 million improvement on the incremental $14 million of revenue that I called out.
We did have a lower incentive compensation accrual for the first quarter this year compared to last year, reflecting some of the headwinds that we experienced with oil and gas, weather and currency. So that contributed $6 million of year-over-year improvement. Used equipment sales or we called out the sales margin improvement, that was about $5 million of improvement. And then a few headwind items. Fleet inflation and mix component combined was about a $13 million headwind versus last year. Bad debt expense, we reverted to a more normal bad debt expense this year compared to a solid bad debt expense performance last year. So that cost us about $8 million in year-over-year EBITDA and then merit increases were about $6 million of impact this year as well. That leaves about $3 million of all other this and that's combined. So all in all, a very robust EBITDA result in the quarter even in spite of the headwinds.
And as Mike called out on EPS, it was a great EPS result for the quarter as well, $1.34. That's up almost 50% against the $0.90 of adjusted EPS that we delivered in the first quarter last year. So another good results there. 
Moving on to free cash flow, continuing the good result commentary. $450 million of free cash flow in the first quarter and that's up from $278 million in the first quarter of last year, with minimal merger-related adjustments showing up in the current quarters, it's only about $1 million worth of merger-related payments. So the way we talk about free cash flow on an adjusted basis, we would call $451 million, a variety of different drivers, including the operating profitability, we also had lower AER and the timing of some of the other working capital payments were also favorable for us primarily accounts payable.
Rental CapEx for the quarter was $323 million. And that's certainly a start consistent with the comments we've made previously about the timing of CapEx this year looking similar to last year. As you saw in the outlook, we continue to expect to spend $1.7 billion in gross capital this year for a net of about $1.2 billion. The net rental CapEx for the quarter was just under $210 million for the quarter. 
On capital structure and liquidity, a busy quarter in capital structure actions. You all have seen that we refinanced 2 of outstanding issues. We issued calls on the 8 3/8% senior subordinated notes and the 5 3/4% senior notes. We refinanced those issues by issuing 2 new issues, $1 billion of 4 5/8% 8-year senior secured notes and then another $800 million worth of 10-year senior unsecured. Very attractive overall impact for those refinancing transactions but we didn't stop there. We also amended and extended our ABL facility and increased its size as well. So the ABL is now up to $2.5 billion. We then drew on that new and improved ABL and used it to partially call the 8 1/4 % senior notes. And I go through all of that just to note that the timing of those transactions were split between first quarter and second quarter and so as you think about the results in the first quarter and as you anticipate the results for the second quarter, you have to remind yourself that we will have some impact in the second quarter from those first quarter transactions. In particular, we'll report in the second quarter about $121 million loss on the redemptions that covers both the premium of calling the outstanding notes, as well as writing off any remaining deferred financing costs that will happen in the second quarter. When you aggregate it altogether, we expect that the aggregate run rate of interest expense reductions from all of those transactions should come in to an improvement of about $40 million -- $48 million a year. So that gives you a summary. And to put it even more directly, our interest expense estimate for cash interest this year, we -- excuse me GAAP interest, GAAP interest this year, we expect to be about $460 million. So hopefully, that will help you as you think through all those transactions.
Real briefly on ROIC. A company record ROIC result in the quarter, 9%. And that was 120 basis points compared to the first quarter last year and 20 basis points better than in the fourth quarter. So despite all the headwinds, as Michael discussed, we continue to be on a path to improving our ROIC, which has been a major focus of our efforts.
And even with the revised guidance that we provided, we fully expect a very nice improvement in ROIC as we go through the full 2015 year.
Before I do finish up with the outlook, just a real brief summary of our progress in oil and gas. We talked in the first quarter about a downside oil and gas scenario. And I just to want to provide a couple of data point about progress against oil and gas and how we compare to that downside.
Recall that we -- we called out about a $400 million maximum fleet size impact from the downside scenario we laid out. You'll also recall that we said that $400 million impact, we modeled it as hitting us in the second quarter. Obviously, we didn't expect it would be 0 impact until June and then $400 million from June on. But we certainly modeled it that way. So that's $400 million maximum impact, averaged out to a $200 million OEC impact over the course of 2015.
We are about halfway to that $400 million maximum impact, just based on the path of fleet in our oil and gas branches. And in particular, when you look at those oil and gas branches, most of the impact that we've seen has come from the oil and gas branches that have the highest share of the revenue from oil and gas. If the branch has more than 20% of the revenue from oil and gas, in aggregate, those have seen about a $200 million equivalent OEC impact. For the branches that have less than 20% of their share in oil and gas, there's been virtually no impact. So we find that a very interesting feature of how oil and gas is progressing throughout our branches.
The thing, as Mike pointed out, that surprised us a little bit is that the impact came a little sooner than what we expected. But certainly, not outside the context of the size of what we expected. But the fact that it came sooner means that it will have an effect over the remainder of the year, longer than the way we modeled the downside. So when you net it all together, we're probably seeing an impact through the full 2015 calendar year of something in the area of 88% of the full downside the impact that we talked about previously.
We called that $36 million of EBITDA, as you will recall. And so we'd probably say that we're seeing something like a $32 million EBITDA impact, assuming oil and gas maintains at the level that it is currently.
That is not an unreasonable assumption, given that when we look at our oil and gas branches, we are seeing a slowdown in the decline. In fact, if you look at all of our oil and gas branches, for the month of March and so far in April, we've actually seen a slight sequential increase in fleet on rent in those branches. So that gives us some level of encouragement that the decline has slowed if not, completely arrested. The question is where does it go from from here? And that's going to be the wildcard and we can talk more about that in Q&A, if anybody's interested.
So that's the oil and gas picture at a very high level. The last thing I'd like to update is just the outlook. You saw the announcement, essentially what we do is to take off the top end of the revenue and EBITDA ranges, reduce the expected rental rates realization and left everything else unchanged. And we think that's a very realistic view of where we will be for 2015. So the outlook now is for rental revenue -- excuse me total revenue, total revenue in the range of $6 billion to $6.1 billion. And within that, as I said, we expect rental rates to be approximately 3% for the full year. Time, we haven't changed our review, 69% for the full year or an increase of about 20 basis points. And then adjusted EBITDA, we're now in the range of $2,950,000,000 to $3 billion for that measure. We're continuing to target $1.7 billion of gross capital spend for a net of about $1.2 billion and we continue to expect free cash flow to be centered around $750 million, with $725 million on the low side and $775 million on the high side. All of that will net out to our continued expectation of leverage at the end of the year up about 2.6x net debt-to-EBITDA. And that assumes that we complete the share repurchase program at about $500 million in calendar 2015. You all saw that we did spend about $316 million on share repurchases in the first quarter. That brought in about 3.5 million shares at an average price of about $89.16 in the quarter. And we continued to believe that spending on the path of $500 million is the right place to be for right now for 2015. Obviously, we'll continue to reevaluate as we see how profitability and cash flow develop, as well as how the stock price trades.
So those are the key points that I wanted to make and certainly, we welcome all of your questions. It was a solid quarter for us. When you step back and look at the results, with some headwinds that not only had we to deal with in the first quarter, we'll have to continue to deal with going forward. But we've got confidence that we've got a program that can get us to outlook that we've given. And certainly, we'll update you as we go forward. So we with that, operator, I'll ask you to open up the call for questions and answers. Operator?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from that line of Seth Weber from RBC Capital.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from that line of Seth Weber from RBC Capital.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm wondering, can you talk a little bit more about the redeployment? Bill, I think you mentioned you've seen about $200 million of fleet that's been affected so far, in the oil and gas regions. I mean, can you size for us how much fleet you've redeployed
componenttext: I'm wondering, can you talk a little bit more about the redeployment? Bill, I think you mentioned you've seen about $200 million of fleet that's been affected so far, in the oil and gas regions. I mean, can you size for us how much fleet you've redeployed year-to-date so far? Where is it going? Is it going intra region? Is it going out of state to just nonresidential construction markets? And I guess, can you talk how do you think the nonres markets are going to shape up competitively. We've heard anecdotally about the independents kind of adding more fleet recently. I think Michael, you mentioned competitive pricing. So can you help us kind of frame all of that stuff?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Seth. I'll start with sizing and Mike and Matt, you guys if want to chime in on where it's going. The way we look at it, we've got about $80 million of fleet that have come out of oil and gas branches going into non-oil and gas branches. And primari
componenttext: Sure, Seth. I'll start with sizing and Mike and Matt, you guys if want to chime in on where it's going. The way we look at it, we've got about $80 million of fleet that have come out of oil and gas branches going into non-oil and gas branches. And primarily that $80 million has come out of the branches that more than 20% share of branches that I mentioned earlier. So the issue has been concentrating in those high share oil and gas branches and we responded there with a deflating of about $80 million so far. The challenge, of course, is putting that fleet on rent usefully elsewhere. We think we stepped up to the challenge. It is more of a challenge in the first part of the year than it will be the second and third quarters in particular, just given the relative business of those quarters compared to first quarter. So we're encouraged by our ability to mitigate by moving fleet around. As to where it's going and sort of the environment that it's facing, you guys want to add anything?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Bill. Yes, so we're seeing and you can look at the construction growth maps that are on the deck on Slide 14, specifically on where the demand is. And we're seeing shipping the assets to where the demand is. The good news, as Bill said, that demand
componenttext: Sure, Bill. Yes, so we're seeing and you can look at the construction growth maps that are on the deck on Slide 14, specifically on where the demand is. And we're seeing shipping the assets to where the demand is. The good news, as Bill said, that demand will increase as we get into our -- the seasonal uptick will be in our favor. And as we look at our non-oil and gas branches, the encouraging news is that they're acting very similar to how we expected them to act how they've acted in the past. And as we sit here today, we're seeing both time and sequential rate in those non-oil and gas branches to get the ramp up that we need to hit our goal. So that's where it's going to go. The end markets and the demand tell us that the opportunity is there and most importantly, we have the team and the customers and the footprint to deploy it there.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would just only add that I think you asked a question where is it going and it's actually most of it's staying within the region where it's coming off rent. We are doing the transfers. We are also doing sales and redeployment of capital. That's an
componenttext: Yes, I would just only add that I think you asked a question where is it going and it's actually most of it's staying within the region where it's coming off rent. We are doing the transfers. We are also doing sales and redeployment of capital. That's an ongoing effort for us and we'll continue to do that. But I also want to point out 1 thing, if you recall over the last several years, we have been very disciplined in the way in which we've given out capital. And over the years, many of our non-oil and gas regions have been looking for fleet. So this is their opportunity. They're taking it, and we're supplying them.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And if I could just on as a follow-up to that, I mean, can you just talk about, I mean, how deep into the year -- where do you expect to make the CapEx, your $1.7 billion CapEx decision, where do we kind of get to the fork in the road on the $1.7 bi
componenttext: Okay. And if I could just on as a follow-up to that, I mean, can you just talk about, I mean, how deep into the year -- where do you expect to make the CapEx, your $1.7 billion CapEx decision, where do we kind of get to the fork in the road on the $1.7 billion number? Is it if you don't see trends pick up in, is it May or June? Or how deep into the construction season will go with that, versus just beginning to move more fleet around?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll start, Seth, and then the guys chime in, please. I think maybe it would be helpful to come at it from the other direction. How late can we go before we have to make a decision about reducing CapEx if we decide it there. And the answer is, pretty
componenttext: Yes, I'll start, Seth, and then the guys chime in, please. I think maybe it would be helpful to come at it from the other direction. How late can we go before we have to make a decision about reducing CapEx if we decide it there. And the answer is, pretty late. I mean as we talked before, we don't have a lot of -- we don't have cancellation penalties or a lot of constraints in our ability to pull back once we placed orders up until the point that it shipped, we can cancel it for the most part. And so that gives us a tremendous runway to make that call. Certainly, we want to see how the second quarter ramps up and get a real solid feel for that before we start making any decision. Matt, I don't know if you want to add anything?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, the only thing I'd add, Seth, is we're not -- we don't need to make that decision and we're not trending towards worst decision position because if you look at the data, when you take Pumps out of the question even absorbing oil and gas, we're 10 bps
componenttext: Yes, the only thing I'd add, Seth, is we're not -- we don't need to make that decision and we're not trending towards worst decision position because if you look at the data, when you take Pumps out of the question even absorbing oil and gas, we're 10 bps down in the first quarter. And that's improving. When you look at the nonoil and gas branches in Q1, they were actually 40 bps up on a year-over-year basis. So if we deliver 3% rate, 79% time, that's a good reason to spend that $1.7 billion. We do have the flexibility in case anything changes, as Bill stated. But we feel good about being able to deploy that, as well as 18 cold starts that we're doing in the full year, many of which are opened already. So actually it's 21, it's 18 specialty and 3 gen rent cold starts that we've already opened up. So those are all the reasons why we feel like deploying the capital is something that we'll be able to do effectively.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, it was 69% time, not 79%.
componenttext: Yes, it was 69% time, not 79%.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Did I say 79? Boy, I had my Nirvana hat on, I apologize.
componenttext: Did I say 79? Boy, I had my Nirvana hat on, I apologize.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could walk through the sequential progression of time utilization in 1Q and then frame out kind of like what's happened in April? What gives you confidence that trajectory can reverse out that a lot of the challenges are reversing o
componenttext: I was wondering if you could walk through the sequential progression of time utilization in 1Q and then frame out kind of like what's happened in April? What gives you confidence that trajectory can reverse out that a lot of the challenges are reversing out? I know you mentioned that the oil and gas branches, that rate of decline has slowed dramatically. But could you just maybe help quantify that with some of that time utilization data points that you can talk about?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, tab. It's Matt. So the time utilization in January was 63.7% and in February, it was 63.9% and in March, it was 64.9%. And when we talk about April, we see that gap that we -- March was our biggest gap on a year-over-year perspective. We see that ga
componenttext: Sure, tab. It's Matt. So the time utilization in January was 63.7% and in February, it was 63.9% and in March, it was 64.9%. And when we talk about April, we see that gap that we -- March was our biggest gap on a year-over-year perspective. We see that gap narrowing and as we sit here today, we're very close to -- and this is all in. This is not just nonoil and gas. We're very close to being on top of year-over-year time utilization. More importantly, as we look at the OEC-on-Rent build, we've had a very strong 2 weeks and this is when we need that to build April, May and June, right? Q2  is when the build had to come and we're expecting to cross over the year-over-year time utilization, somewhere in mid-May. That's our target, and that's what got to happen and then have some sequential improvements from there on a year-over-year basis, as well as seasonal increase. So that's -- I don't know if I answered your question, that's the data  that we're sharing today.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's helpful. I think that helps people understand what that curve looks like. And then I think -- did you mentioned that in the first quarter, nonoil and gas branches, time utilization's up 40 basis points?
componenttext: Yes, that's helpful. I think that helps people understand what that curve looks like. And then I think -- did you mentioned that in the first quarter, nonoil and gas branches, time utilization's up 40 basis points?

componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. The second thing I wanted to ask was just -- is a follow-on to Seth's question on the oil and gas exposure. A quarter ago you walked through the framework it was very helpful. You've updated to say that the reasonable worst-case scen
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. The second thing I wanted to ask was just -- is a follow-on to Seth's question on the oil and gas exposure. A quarter ago you walked through the framework it was very helpful. You've updated to say that the reasonable worst-case scenario is 88% of that $36 million. Did I hear that correctly? Is that -- do you still feel that the reasonable worst-case scenario is that $36 million or I just want to make sure we understand what the updated kind of message is in the on the framework.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we do still think that's a reasonable way to think about maximum downside, Ted, as I said, the impact came sooner in the year than what we modeled certainly and then what we expected, quite honestly. So but yes, I'd still say that $36 million is a re
componenttext: Yes, we do still think that's a reasonable way to think about maximum downside, Ted, as I said, the impact came sooner in the year than what we modeled certainly and then what we expected, quite honestly. So but yes, I'd still say that $36 million is a reasonable downside scenario. Remember, when I said [ph] the 88%, the $32 million I think I said of impact is our view right now. That's, excluding some of the mitigation that we have been and will be doing over the course of the year. That $80 million of fleet that I said came out of oil and gas and went into other nonoil and gas branches, we haven't given any benefit for mitigation from that fleet being moved the way it has. So that's why we think that the $36 million is still a reasonable downside for EBITDA impact from oil and gas this year.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, and so the last thing I wanted to ask, when we square that up against the updated EBITDA guidance, $2.95 billion to $3.0 billion, you can kind of fit 25 at the midpoint. How much of that is the updated oil and gas expectations, just so we understand
componenttext: Okay, and so the last thing I wanted to ask, when we square that up against the updated EBITDA guidance, $2.95 billion to $3.0 billion, you can kind of fit 25 at the midpoint. How much of that is the updated oil and gas expectations, just so we understand how that's baked into the updated guidance?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we weren't that explicit when we set the range and therefore set the mid-point on the new guidance, Ted. What I would say is that what we feel is that if oil and gas continues where it is now or even deteriorate a little bit more, it would have been
componenttext: Yes, we weren't that explicit when we set the range and therefore set the mid-point on the new guidance, Ted. What I would say is that what we feel is that if oil and gas continues where it is now or even deteriorate a little bit more, it would have been a part of the reduction in the midpoint of the range but not the entire reduction, right? We still certainly have the impact of currency that's continuing throughout the course of the year. We still -- we did have the weather impact and we're going to claw our way back from that in the second quarter here that continued to impact the full year. So I don't know how to characterize it numerically but I'd say oil and gas was part of it but everything that we experienced and everything else experience in this first quarter was part of it as well.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: The only thing I'd add, Ted, is that there's a $25 million number on rate, right? So just the absorbing that 0.5 point of rate change is part of that, is part of that movement as well.
componenttext: The only thing I'd add, Ted, is that there's a $25 million number on rate, right? So just the absorbing that 0.5 point of rate change is part of that, is part of that movement as well.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So my first question is just clarifying Ted's point. So the $32 million, and I'm sorry if we're going on about this, but the $32 million impact that you guys now expect from oil and gas, is that fully baked into to your guidance? Like is it in the low end
componenttext: So my first question is just clarifying Ted's point. So the $32 million, and I'm sorry if we're going on about this, but the $32 million impact that you guys now expect from oil and gas, is that fully baked into to your guidance? Like is it in the low end or is it in the midpoint is it in the high end of your new EBITDA range?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: It is baked into our guidance. We were not correct characterizing whether it puts us at the low, medium or high end. It's in our thinking when we set the guidance this time.
componenttext: It is baked into our guidance. We were not correct characterizing whether it puts us at the low, medium or high end. It's in our thinking when we set the guidance this time.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks for clarifying that. And my second question is, it seems to me like the new 3% rate guidance is assuming that we kind of get normal senility from here, which makes sense as you guys are already starting to see a pickup in those oil and gas st
componenttext: Okay, thanks for clarifying that. And my second question is, it seems to me like the new 3% rate guidance is assuming that we kind of get normal senility from here, which makes sense as you guys are already starting to see a pickup in those oil and gas states but I guess my question is what you've seen from a rates perspective quarter-to-date, so in early April, does that [indiscernible] with the 3% rate guidance you have and what's the downside risk at this point that we could have a downward revision, would we need to see deterioration in oil and gas prices in markets for that outcome to occur?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Nicole. I'll take that. It's Matt. As far as rate guidance, what we've seen in April is that we've gotten it back to flat and now we can get our sequential climbs that we need, that as you pointed out, we usually get in this season and you're lookin
componenttext: Sure, Nicole. I'll take that. It's Matt. As far as rate guidance, what we've seen in April is that we've gotten it back to flat and now we can get our sequential climbs that we need, that as you pointed out, we usually get in this season and you're looking at about 6/10 a month May through November and then a small drop in December and something that looks similar to that. The good news is as we look at our history, we've done that before. So between the strengthening end markets and the fact that we have the tools and the capability of doing it is why we felt comfortable setting the target at 3.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015

componenttext: Our next question comes from that line of Scott Schneeberger from Oppenheimer.

componenttext: Yes, just curious with regard to the guidance. And the softness in the quarter with regard to rates. Could you address ForEx? I think you talked about the rental revenue impacting the quarter. Could you speak to EBITDA and then to just other drivers of the rate guidance. Is it predominantly the oil impact or there are other things, asset class, geographies, just curious?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So on currency, I called out $15 million of revenue impact in rental revenue, and about $7 million in EBITDA. As we look through the full year, currency stays [indiscernible] you can use $60 million and $30 million as the full year impacts for the remaind
componenttext: So on currency, I called out $15 million of revenue impact in rental revenue, and about $7 million in EBITDA. As we look through the full year, currency stays [indiscernible] you can use $60 million and $30 million as the full year impacts for the remainder of 2015. And that is considered in our guidance as well. So that's the currency story. And then I'm sorry, what was the other part of your question, Scott?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's helpful on that, Bill. Just as a follow on. Let's go with when moving around assets from the oil locations, what -- could you speak to the asset class that being moved and what's just coming off and not going back and what are the asset classes tha
componenttext: That's helpful on that, Bill. Just as a follow on. Let's go with when moving around assets from the oil locations, what -- could you speak to the asset class that being moved and what's just coming off and not going back and what are the asset classes that you're moving? And what's having more success than not and how that ties to great as well? Thanks, Bill.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Scott. This is Matt. So as far as the assets that are moving, what you'd expects would be forklifts and booms, light towers as well as pumps. If you ask me, which one is the most challenge to move, until we further build out our footprint, we have a
componenttext: Sure, Scott. This is Matt. So as far as the assets that are moving, what you'd expects would be forklifts and booms, light towers as well as pumps. If you ask me, which one is the most challenge to move, until we further build out our footprint, we have a headwind to moving the pumps as fast as we move the other more fungible assets. But that was always our game plan when we made the pump acquisition was to grow out that footprint and penetrate other markets, as well as chasing our cross-sell opportunity. You will see in the slide deck on I think it's Slide 35 that we've identified $80 million of cross-sell opportunity. So we don't only have the strategy and hope, we actually have the opportunity to continue to move some of those Pumps out of the oil and gas and into existing customers through cross-sell. So stay tuned for what our close rate will be but there's an opportunity out there that we have identified and we're chasing that it will be the last part of the asset class that we need to move more aggressively and it would be the Pumps.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Joe Box from KeyBanc.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015

componenttext: Mike, you said earlier that you expect a competitive rate environment as we start to get into summer months. I'm curious, is that across the board was that much more concentrated in the energy-exposed markets? And I apologize if I missed this earlier but did you can give us a breakdown of rental rates within the energy markets versus outside?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't think we gave the -- it's hard for us to break it out that way because the way in which we do it the ARA weighted average on the asset class and it's hard to break it out that way. With regards to the competitive marketplace, yes, I think it's typ
componenttext: I don't think we gave the -- it's hard for us to break it out that way because the way in which we do it the ARA weighted average on the asset class and it's hard to break it out that way. With regards to the competitive marketplace, yes, I think it's typical look, we all had a bad winter. We all had the oil and we see that the competitive marketplace will change as the season swings to the more seasonal opportunity. So we just need to be more competitive. I wouldn't take it anything more than that. And that's in a nutshell.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015

componenttext: I would say that, I would quantify it by saying that the non-O&G, you'd a normal trend that you would normally see that we've experienced over time as opposed to what we -- with the when you add the O&G in, it gives us that full impact.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Understood. One last one for you. Bill, looks like there's only about a $6 million difference between the revenue contribution that you're getting from rental rates and then the offset from fleet inflation. And that doesn't give you a whole lot of wiggle
componenttext: Understood. One last one for you. Bill, looks like there's only about a $6 million difference between the revenue contribution that you're getting from rental rates and then the offset from fleet inflation. And that doesn't give you a whole lot of wiggle room. We know where you're guiding for rental rates but what are your expectations for fleet inflation? Kind of curious if rental rates continue to exceed inflation or if they go to parity or even negative from here?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so the expectation is for fleet inflation to continue sort of the trend that it's been right. We're replacing something like 15% of our fleet every year and we continue to experience inflation on new purchases at something like a couple of percent a
componenttext: Yes, so the expectation is for fleet inflation to continue sort of the trend that it's been right. We're replacing something like 15% of our fleet every year and we continue to experience inflation on new purchases at something like a couple of percent a year. So when you aggregate that over the average life of what we're replacing. We're going to stay in that 2% area for fleet inflation going forward and so if we deliver the above 3% that we're talking about for rental rates, we still got it spread. My expectation is that the inflation won't change dramatically and I certainly expect that we'll continue to drive rates as hard as we can. So I won't give you a long range forecast. We talked about delivering  3% a year rental rate improvement over the long haul for a long time. That's been our long-term view. Oil and gas has made that challenging this year but I don't see a reason to change that longer-term view as we sit right here.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Joe, I would only add that aside from just rate, it's not only the thing that we're leaning on. We're also looking at driving efficiencies in our process improvements. We continue to march down that path and so we're looking at ways in which we can b
componenttext: Yes, Joe, I would only add that aside from just rate, it's not only the thing that we're leaning on. We're also looking at driving efficiencies in our process improvements. We continue to march down that path and so we're looking at ways in which we can be more efficient in driving not only our fleet but also our cost structure around the rental process.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of David Raso from Evercore ISI.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: The rest of the year guidance, the first quarter incremental EBITDA number was -- the margin was pretty healthy, it was 61%. But when you look at the rest of the year guidance, it requires a bit of a step-up where the incremental EBITDA margins has to be
componenttext: The rest of the year guidance, the first quarter incremental EBITDA number was -- the margin was pretty healthy, it was 61%. But when you look at the rest of the year guidance, it requires a bit of a step-up where the incremental EBITDA margins has to be around 76% to hit the year. So I'm just trying to walk-through is there some cost reductions that we can think about to expect incremental EBITDA margin to accelerate that much as the year goes on or a mix issue? If you can dive into that a little bit more.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks, David. So I called out the impact of 1 particular item, bonus accrual difference year-over-year was $6 million in the first quarter. If we continue on the path that we're on, that's going to continue to contribute as we go throughout the rest
componenttext: Yes, thanks, David. So I called out the impact of 1 particular item, bonus accrual difference year-over-year was $6 million in the first quarter. If we continue on the path that we're on, that's going to continue to contribute as we go throughout the rest of the year. In fact the contribution will increase because last year, we increased our bonus accrual as the year wore on. The second half, we ran very strong versus our plan. And so we accrued up to a much higher level for last year's bonus. This year, assuming we stay and deliver the guidance that we've given, it's going to be less. And so that $6 million will go up a little bit in future quarters. So that will help. And as you know the incremental margin impact patient is very sensitive even if it's a reasonably small dollar amount. So I think that's one example. To Mike's point, we've got a very intense focus on productivity overall. We realized what was the number, guys, $7 million of year-to-date impact of our efficiency, our lean focus and that set a run rate of $42 million. So we'll continue to drive that run rate higher and the realized amount higher as we go forward as well. So that's going to contribute and help support the incremental margin. And then I'd say bad debt expense, it's always a little bit of a wildcard but we think that there could an opportunity in bad debt expense as we drive some process change internally to focus on how effectively we collect. So I think those are the things that I'd point to you that give us some confidence that the 60% flow-through margin or flow through that we talked about is very realistic for the year.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015

componenttext: Would you help me -- given that's fully under your control, so something you really could just make happen if you need to, can you help us a little bit more in quantifying potential benefit from the accrual in the bonus? So just to give us more comfort that, that is a lever you could pull, I mean, can that had not 6% in the second quarter and third quarter, could it be 20s and 30s? I mean, is that a significant number?

I would think you made that decision probably as you said, by the end of the second quarter if not, maybe a little bit earlier. What's the cadence or rate increases year-over-year that we should be thinking about to help think about that trigger decision on CapEx?

componenttext: So if you do the math, you will see you that you don't cross to 3 -- you don't get to the 3 threshold until the second half of the year. So we understand that. We understand that's a headwind that we got in Q1 compounds and has a carryover effect to our Q2 results when you look at the year-over-year and that's within our modeling and where we're expecting. So you're talking  towards the end of the third quarter and then moving on from there.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of George Tong from Piper Jaffray.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I want to drill into the downside scenario. In your prior earnings call, you noted $400 million of fleet would be affected by oil and gas. And then you assume you could mitigate half of that by redeploying the fleet, so that's about $200 million of fleet
componenttext: I want to drill into the downside scenario. In your prior earnings call, you noted $400 million of fleet would be affected by oil and gas. And then you assume you could mitigate half of that by redeploying the fleet, so that's about $200 million of fleet affected, then previously you had assumed, you expected only a half year impact so that works out to be 100 million of fleet affected. 100 million of fleet, assuming 60% dollar utilization gives you $60 million of revenue impact and then $60 million revenues on 60% EBITDA flow-through gets you to the $36 million EBITDA downside. So it appears your prior downside of $36 million assumes a half year impact and assumes you can mitigate the downside by redeploying the fleet. So given the greater part of the year is being affected by oil, does that increase the downside beyond $36 million?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's why I was trying to call out the fact that we've now experienced the equivalent of a $200 million decline for now it's going to be 3 quarters, assuming it doesn't get any worse or doesn't get any better. It will be 3 quarters of $200 million o
componenttext:
Yes, that's why I was trying to call out the fact that we've now experienced the equivalent of a $200 million decline for now it's going to be 3 quarters, assuming it doesn't get any worse or doesn't get any better. It will be 3 quarters of $200 million of impact and 1 quarter at an average of 0 to $200 million. So call it a net effect of $175 million of impact before mitigation. And then the math flows through from there to that 88% or $32 million number that I gave earlier. But the mitigation I want to point out, the mitigation is not included in that calculation. On the $80 million of fleet that came out of oil and gas and went somewhere else, right? We would have to do a separate calculation of the mitigation impact of that and that's why I said that I don't believe it will be a full $32 million impact that we'll experience but something less than that and I tried to range it between $18 million and $36 million. And you'd probably say $18 million and $32 million as the realistic range. So that's how we're thinking about it this year. And obviously, it requires us to continue to mitigate pretty aggressively with the fleet that does come out of oil and gas. And as I pointed out, that's harder to do in the first order of the year, in the first quarter, than it is when things get busy in the second and third quarters. So we're encouraged about our ability to mitigate even more effectively as we go forward.
Hopefully, that answers, if not, ask again, George.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: That makes sense. If I look at your updated guidance range for revenues and EBITDA, at the midpoint of the range, EBITDA flow-through works out to be 70%, however, you're still maintaining the 60% flow-through target for the full year. So this suggests ei
componenttext: That makes sense. If I look at your updated guidance range for revenues and EBITDA, at the midpoint of the range, EBITDA flow-through works out to be 70%, however, you're still maintaining the 60% flow-through target for the full year. So this suggests either EBITDA will be below the midpoint or revenues will be above the mid-point or both? Can you comment on which of these you're thinking about as you target a 60% flow-through?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is where the range has always made life challenging, right? I mean, what I would -- I don't want to go further than just the ranges that we've given and the fact that we believe that revenue and EBITDA will fall within the range given the sensit
componenttext: Yes. This is where the range has always made life challenging, right? I mean, what I would -- I don't want to go further than just the ranges that we've given and the fact that we believe that revenue and EBITDA will fall within the range given the sensitivity of the calculation, the combination of those 2 will get you to, we think at least to be about 60% flow-through that we expect. And not going further than that, George, otherwise we might as well just give you the whole forecast we have and that might be happy for some of you but not for us.
