headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to United Rentals Second Quarter 2015 Investor Conference Call. Please be advised that this call is being recorded.Before we begin, note that the company's press release, comments made on today's call and responses to your ques
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to United Rentals Second Quarter 2015 Investor Conference Call. Please be advised that this call is being recorded.
Before we begin, note that the company's press release, comments made on today's call and responses to your questions contain forward-looking statements. The company's business and operations are subject to a variety of risks, uncertainties, many of which are beyond its control, and consequently, actual results may differ materially from those projected.
A summary of these uncertainties is included in the Safe Harbor statement contained in the company's earnings release. For a more complete description of these and other possible risks, please refer to the company's annual report on Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2014, as well as to subsequent filings with the SEC. You can access these filings on the company's website at www.ur.com.
Please note that United Rentals has no obligation and makes no commitment to update or publicly release any revisions to forward-looking statements in order to reflect new information or subsequent events, circumstances or changes in expectation. You should also note that the company's earnings release, investor presentation and today's call include references to free cash flow, adjusted EPS, EBITDA and adjusted EBITDA, each of which is a non-GAAP term.
Speaking today for United Rentals is Michael Kneeland, Chief Executive Officer; William Plummer, Chief Financial Officer; and Matt Flannery, Chief Operating Officer.
I will now turn the call over to Mr. Kneeland. Mr. Kneeland, you may begin.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you, and good morning, everyone, and welcome. I want to thank everybody for joining us on today's call. I want to focus most of my comments today on the dynamics of our operating environment, I'll discuss how our industry is adjusting to the
componenttext:
Well, thank you, and good morning, everyone, and welcome. I want to thank everybody for joining us on today's call. 
I want to focus most of my comments today on the dynamics of our operating environment, I'll discuss how our industry is adjusting to the recovery and I'll talk about the nonresidential construction is hitting its stride, particularly in the commercial sector. And then Bill will cover the financial results followed by your questions.
So first, look at the quarter. We turned in a solid performance with nice gains and profitability, margin and returns. Our EBITDA margin increased over 49% in the quarter, and we reported earnings per share of $1.95 on an adjusted basis. And these were both second quarter record for us.
Free cash flow is very strong at $432 million through June. Now taking into an entirety, these numbers reflect the fundamental strength of our operating environment. There's clear evidence of demand for our equipment and demand is growing.
However, taking individually, 2 of the underlying metrics reflects some challenges in our environment, their rate and time utilization. They came in softer than expected at 1.5% higher year-over-year, and time utilization was down 150 basis points to 66.6%.
And it's important to understand what these numbers do and don't represent. For 1 thing, they do not reflect the macro weakness in demand. Now we spent a lot of time analyzing industry behavior, and we believe that rental demand in North America has multiple years of growth ahead.
We also think that 2016 will be even stronger than 2015 for our end markets and that the growth will be led by nonresidential construction spending. And that's what most industry experts believe, and we agree.
Now what the metrics point to are 2 dynamics that are more like micro cycles within our larger operating environment. These dynamics will run their course but right now, they're not doing us any favors.
The first issue is upstream oil and gas. Last quarter, we told you this sector was a significant constraint with both a direct and knock-on-effect. And I'll give you an idea of the impact in the second quarter. If we exclude the branches with the most exposure of upstream oil and gas, time utilization was only down 30 basis points year-over-year and sequential rates was slightly positive.
In April, we said, we thought this sector would continue to be a drag on numbers to at least the third quarter. So it's no surprise that we're still dealing with that challenge, particularly in our pump operations.
So obviously, there's not much we can do about the price of oil but we are taking actions. So far, we've are deployed over $125 million of fleet away from the Upstream oil and gas markets and will continue to use this lever where we see the opportunity for higher returns.
The second dynamic is on the supply side, where it's more of a timing issue with our industry as a whole. Right now, Rouse will tell you that there are some excess fleet that needs to be absorbed into the marketplace. It's not unusual for our industry to add fleet in an and do so slightly in advance of the demand.
In this case, however, the imbalance was exaggerated by the decline of upstream oil and gas. This will allow but until that happens, it continue to be a drag on rates and digitalization.
Our own plan is to invest $1.6 billion of gross CapEx this year, which is $100 million less than our original projection. Now why we've taken that number down, it's still represents plenty of growth CapEx to serve our large accounts and to expand our high-margin specialty business.
On the other side of CapEx management, we used equipment sales, the market is growing strong. Used sales continue to be an important mechanism for us in fleet management.
In the second quarter, our adjusted margin on used sales was a robust 50%, which is an increase over last year. Now giving these various considerations, we're being realistic about the short-term impact on our performance.
And as you saw last night, we lowered our expectation on rate to a 0.5% gain. Time utilization target is now approximately 67.5% and we've adjust our revenue and EBITDA ranges accordingly.
At the same time, we expect free cash flow to remain very strong. Now one of the clear about our higher than its outlook as it always are with any guidance we give. I think you know by know that our nature is to be hungry for more. And in this case, if there's more rate, we're going to find it.
We have a lot of runway ahead of us in this cycle, secular penetration is still in play and commercial construction is nowhere near its peak. Global Insight is forecasting solid growth for the U.S. rental industry this year, followed by similar increases in 2016 and 2017. And see the construction market growing for at least the next 3 years.
At the same time, we're careful to maintain our company in a strong position to handle any issues that can arise. We've been building our scale, technology, processes, our scale sets for nearly 2 decades. And even if the environment throws us a curveball, we can handle it. In fact, we're better equipped to handle it now than any time in our history.
From our current vantage point, the cycle is right on track. We're finding the customers are bullish about their prospects and the level of activity activity seems to bear that out. In some case, we're hearing about project backlogs that are approaching prerecession levels. I'll give you a few snapshots from the field.
In our mid-Atlantic region, where we had double-digit growth in the quarter, won a nuclear Power presents, roads, bridges and industrial manufacturing plants. In the Southeast, we're seeing government projects start-up as well as health care construction and highway expansion. Florida has picked up. And customers are saying they expect a strong finish to the year, with upside into 2016. And in the Midwest, where heavy rains and a labor shortage delayed some bridge construction starts, we still had solid growth. And we're now seeing a range of projects get underway, including a fertilizer plants, manufacturing and commercial buildings. And should give us momentum right through the winter.
Turning to our specialty segment.
Trench Safety, Power & HVAC, all had a stellar quarter. Trench Safety revenue was up 15% year-over-year and Power posted 39% growth.
Our specialty segment got a boost from 10 new branches we opened in the first half the year and we plan to open another 8 before the year-end. But this segment is also generating solid growth organically.
All of the 15% growth in Trench in the quarter came from same-store performance, and Power and HVAC had 27% same-store growth.
Now in addition to being important revenue streams in their own right, specialty rentals have a role in strengthening our key customer relationships. The larger customer, the more likely that the rental needs extend beyond the basics and we're doing a good job of ramping up our cross-selling efforts to serve these accounts were completely. And in a the process, we're building loyalty that holds up in the competitive pressure.
National Accounts are good example. In the year-over-year in Q2, we grew our cross-sell revenue by almost 30% with National Accounts. In the second quarter, we grew our rental revenue in the same group by more than 7%.
So highlighting a steady shape and we're being extremely disciplined our business development efforts. Finally, I want to mention our share repurchase plans. As we announced last night, we're accelerating the $750 million program we initiated last year. We now expect to complete that program before year-end, and then we'll start a new program for additional $1 billion of share repurchases.
It's a sign of our confidence in our future earning power and our commitment to returning value to our stockholders. 
Now on closing, I want to come back on our operating environment and in many levers we have in our disposal. We used these levers and the inherent strengths of our strategic to manage our business to the best possible outcomes. And in the second quarter, you saw the benefit of the organic and inorganic blues we made, our focus on operational excellence, our efficient cost structure and our ability to use scale to our advantage, all of which contributed to a strong financial performance in many respects.
While we'll continue to take the decisive actions where we see opportunity to build on these results and generate even higher returns. So with that, come I'll ask Bill to cover the financial results and then we'll take your questions. Over to you, Bill.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike, and good morning, everyone. I'll try to add a little bit more color to the numbers that most of you have seen in the press release or heard in Mike's remarks.Starting with rental revenue. Rental revenue for the quarter was up 3.5% year-ove
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike, and good morning, everyone. I'll try to add a little bit more color to the numbers that most of you have seen in the press release or heard in Mike's remarks.
Starting with rental revenue. Rental revenue for the quarter was up 3.5% year-over-year, that's $42 million of an increase. Within that increase, owned equipment revenue represented 3.7% year-over-year growth or for about $37 million of that $42 million.
The remaining rounded $4 million was ancillary and re-rent items, which were up nicely over the prior year. Within the OER growth, rental rate, the 1.5% year-over-year rental rate that we delivered in the quarter, equates to about $16 million of the $42 million year-over-year growth. The volume growth, 2.8% volume growth represents about $29 million worth of rental revenue growth year-over-year.
The replacement CapEx we sold -- the replacement CapEx average age of 86.9 months in the quarter, inflating that out over the average life -- those life of equipment that we sold resulting in about 1.9% or $20 million of rental revenue headwind in the quarter.
And that leaves about $12 million of mix and other impacts resulting from the strong growth in specialty and other mix effects throughout the business. So those are the key components of the $42 million year-over-year rental revenue growth. The only other point that I would emphasize is that Canadian currency effects equates throughout all of those lines, with the exception of rental rate. Canadian dollars was weaker by 11% in the quarter and that resulted in about $15 million of headwind in the quarter compared to last year. So significant component to the overall performance.
That said, we still delivered the 3.5% in spite in spite of that particular challenge.
Moving to used equipment sales. We generated $124 million of proceeds from used sales in the quarter. That's down about 10% from the second quarter of last year. And even though the total revenue was down, the margin performance was very good. 50% adjusted margin for our used equipment sales activity. That's 140 basis points better than the prior year. And particularly proud about the fact that we were able to do that while still supporting the overall fleet strategy of selling the oldest fleet, as I mentioned earlier, just under 87 months of average age per fleet told.
Continue to do a good job of disposing of used equipments for our retail channel. Retail represented just over 60% of our sales in the quarter. And that was about 1% better than the share that it represented last year. So a good used equipment result, even a little bit with a slight year-over-year decline.
If we move to adjusted EBITDA. We delivered $706 million of adjusted EBITDA in the quarter. That set a margin of 49.4%, both the records for the second quarter for our company.
That's $43 million of improvement year-over-year and $200 million of greater -- excuse me 200 basis points of greater margin from second quarter last year.
The components of that $43 million improvement year-over-year are as follows: The rental rate improvement resulted in about $15 million of year-over-year EBITDA improvement; volume is about $20 million of improvement; and the ancillary that I called out earlier, all of that $4 million revenue improvement drops to an EBITDA improvement. So nice results there.
Working against these, fleet inflation resulted in about $14 million of impact at EBITDA, and used sales year-over-year was about $5 million of impact at EBITDA, both representing headwinds.
We also had year-over-year bad debt expense increase, so that was a headwind of about $10 million. Didn't represent a problem or challenge in bad debt collections this year. It's just that the comparison period last year was so strong. Last year, we had a really nice collection result, along with an improvement in the aging buckets of our accounts receivable that really took down our bad debt expense last year.
Instead of compensation, was one of the adjustments that we have made in order to offset some of the challenges that Mike mentioned, our incentive comp benefited us year-over-year to the tune of about $18 million for the cash incentive compensation programs across the business. So that was an $18 million benefit. And it helped to offset some of the headwinds that I mentioned previously.
Merit increases are always there. They were about $6 million of headwind for the quarter. And the remainder, which is about a total of $20 million represents mix and other benefits. Of that $20 million, about $10 million is pure mix, whether it's mix from growing specialty, cat class mix, day, week, months mix, all of those mix factors net out to about $10 million of benefit year-over-year. And that leaves about $10 million of all other, which encompasses a wide variety of net benefit. So within that all other, we had fuel low cost saves with the lower price of diesel and gasoline. We had lower professional fees year-over-year, lower T&E and that's where you would see the benefit of our lean and other productivity focused programs.
So those are the pieces of the $43 million of year-over-year improvement in adjusted EBITDA. And here again, I'll call out the impact of currency, which is scattered throughout a number of those lines. When you step back and aggregate it all, currency cost us an unfavorable impact in the quarter about $7 million versus last year.
Flow-through for the quarter, the top line number was very robust, 143%. But I'll remind you that does include the impact of the incentive compensation. If you adjust for that incentive comp, the $18 million, you get that flow-through down to about 83%. I'd also point out that the flow-through was helped by the fact that our year-over-year used equipment sales were lower. We're selling used equipments at roughly 50% margin. That's lower than our margin for the rental business. So when you take out used equipment, you're actually helping the overall flow-through. If you adjust for that used equipment effect, you'll get flow-through that was down around 70%, and still a nice result of 70% in any given quarter. It's more in line with the roughly 6% that we've guided to for the full year.
Looking at adjusted EBITDA. We delivered $1.95 of adjusted EPS -- excuse me adjusted EPS for the quarter. That compares to $1.65 in the second quarter of last year. That's an 18% increase year-over-year. And as I've pointed out for the other measures, it also includes the impact of currency. Absent currency, it would have been about $0.04 higher.
Moving to free cash flow. Year-to-date, we generated free cash flow of $432 million. That includes $2 million of merger-related payments and that compares to $240 million on a comparable basis for the first 6 months of 2014.
The driver of the increase was largely the result of the year-over-year improvement in EBITDA performance, as well as some benefits in other lines, including a variety of other items.
CapEx in the quarter was $693 million and that brings the total first 6 months capital spend for this year to just over $1 billion. And that leaves our net rental CapEx for the second quarter and first 6 months at $570 million and $776 million, respectively.
If we move to capital structure and liquidity. As you know, we took several steps to improve our capital structure in the first quarter with refinancing issues. We issued 2 new notes totaling about $1.8 billion and called a comparable amount of notes out of 3 different issues, either fully or partially during the first quarter.
And as I noted on the first call, the actual settlement for those transactions would happen in the second quarter. And indeed in this quarter, we record a charge of approximately $121 million to cover the redemption and write-off of other amortized cost in the quarter.
The details of all those transactions are in our 10-Q and I'll refer you there if you'd like to see more.
As of June 30, our total liquidity sat at $880 million. And that included a ABL capacity of about $680 million, along with the cash balance of right at $200 million. So we feel we're very well positioned with liquidity.
Mike mentioned the share repurchase program but just to hit a couple of points there. We did continue to execute under the $750 million current authorization during the quarter. We bought $155 million worth of shares. And that brings our total purchases against that program through June 30 up to $573 million, which leaves us with about $177 million to complete that program. Our initial target was that, that program would run until about April 2016. But given our performance, especially the robust cash flow performance as is ruling in this year, we accelerated our time line and now expect to finish that program by the end of this year.
And us Michael also mentioned, we have announced that our board authorized a new $1 billion share repurchase program. That program gram will begin after we've completed the current $750 million program. We put an 18-month time line on execution of the $1 billion, so the 18-month clock will start once we start purchasing under this program.
One thing to mention regarding our share repurchase program. We do have to be mindful of limitations on restricted payment transactions that are inherent in many of our debt notes. As I'm sure most of you are familiar, RP limitations are typical in these notes. And typically, give you a basket, which deals with net income. So as you grow net income, you build up a basket basket gets depleted with RB transactions, of which share repurchases represent 1 type.
At the end of June, we had roughly $400 million of available capacity for executing repurchase or other restricted payments. That $400 million includes the RP basket along with the cash capacity that we have at the hauling company level, which is outside of the respective payment limitations of the operating note issues.
So we have plenty of room. sure and swift we have plenty of room to complete the $750 million program this year and to get deep into the $1 billion program as we execute it over the course of the next 18-months-plus.
On ROIC, the ROIC was for the quarter was 8.9%. And that was an increase of 80 basis points over last year although down slightly from the first quarter sequentially in this year. And the decline really was the result of the way that we calculate ROIC. We use a 5-point average for the IC component in the denominator and then as you cross over the quarter, that includes pump in that 5-point average versus [indiscernible] it had a slight impact on our ROIC on a sequential basis. So certainly, we continue to be in the path as the year-over-year number indicates toward improving our ROIC performance. And as all of you know, that's a very intense focus of our company.
Regarding the outlook for 2015, again, Mike hit most of the key components, but I'll are just add a little bit more color. Our total revenue range is now $5.8 billion to $5.9 billion. Within that, rental revenue will be driven by rate and time utilization assumptions that we've revised. So rate, we now expect up [ph] about 0.5% year-over-year and really, that rate assumptions reflects a very heavily the experience that we've had so far this year.
Time utilization also reflect that experience. Now expect the full year to come in at about 57.5%. And those will result in an adjusted EBITDA a range of about $2.8 billion to $2.85 billion. We have reduced our capital spending plan for the year by $100 million. So net gross capital we now expect to spend about $1.6 billion. And we think this line is -- this change is in line with what we've been focused on very recently, which is the be very disciplined around our CapEx spend.
Free cash flow, we've maintained our range there at $725 million to $775 million. And if we deliver that, we expect the year to end with adjusted debt-to-EBITDA of 2.8x. That's slightly higher than the 2.6x that we've shared in the past. It clearly reflects the decrease in adjusted EBITDA, but it also assumes now the accelerated completion of the $750 million share repurchase program by the end of this year.
So those are the key comments I wanted to make. I just want to reemphasize a couple of the point that Mike made. It is a solid quarter for us, albeit, some headwinds that were more challenging that we certainly expected. Our Upstream oil and gas, that impacts will continue to work through but it just a matter of working through it rather than it being a major impact to the company's longer-term future.
The supply dynamic across the industry is one that we're also focused and making sure that we're focused on adjusting profitably to what we see as a short-term supply dynamic. And, of course, currency is another effect that will continue to play in our future coming up.
But with all of that, the results that we delivered in the quarter represent what I think are our really solid performance, record revenue, record EBITDA, record EBITDA margin, record EPS, all put us in a great position for the future. 
So with that, I'll ask the operator to open us up for questions and answers. Operator?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Ted Grace from Susquehanna.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Ted Grace from Susquehanna.

componenttextpreview: This is Tim Robinson on for Ted. First question I have. I was wondering if you could provide us with a framework for how you see the industry supply situation currently. And how you see that unfolding over the next 3, 6, 9 months?
componenttext: This is Tim Robinson on for Ted. First question I have. I was wondering if you could provide us with a framework for how you see the industry supply situation currently. And how you see that unfolding over the next 3, 6, 9 months?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll start and please Mike and Matt chime in. I think framing it -- I hit in my comments and Mike hit it as well. There is the dynamic of oil and gas is a major factor that we continue to work through, but we feel like we are making good progress and work
componenttext: I'll start and please Mike and Matt chime in. I think framing it -- I hit in my comments and Mike hit it as well. There is the dynamic of oil and gas is a major factor that we continue to work through, but we feel like we are making good progress and working through it. The industry as well is working through it and I think over time, they will as long as there's not a major down leg on oil and gas drilling activity. Given what we we've seen and we've put some more information in our investor deck to share with you the trends that we've seen in oil and gas activity. We think that the impact from oil and gas is stabilizing and even if it goes down a little bit more, it's not going to be a major change from here. The supply dynamic is one that I think we're also very focused on. Some of the midsized and smaller players according to the data that we've seen from Rouse and elsewhere have been growing your fleets in the early part of this year. What we've have seen and heard more recently, let's call it over the last couple of months, is that they are much more attuned to the challenges that the oil and gas dynamic have put to the industry. And so people are no focused more on making more disciplined decisions, we believe, around their supply in the current environment. So that's what frames our thinking that we could work through this supply access, if you will, in the relatively near-term, couple that with the overall demand backdrop that we talked so that will get through this and time should be better going ahead. I don't know if you guys want add anything, Mike or Matt?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, I think Bill you covered it well. When Mike referred to as a time utilization in the nonoil and gas stores, only being down 30 bps. And imagine how much they've had to absorb into those end markets if they're participating in from the oil and gas disl
componenttext: No, I think Bill you covered it well. When Mike referred to as a time utilization in the nonoil and gas stores, only being down 30 bps. And imagine how much they've had to absorb into those end markets if they're participating in from the oil and gas dislocation, as well as everybody getting a little bit ahead of their fleet purchases said that's an encouraging sign the kind that holds our opinion.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Tim. Just the way we characterize it is that July rate is very much in line with our expectation for the remainder of the year. Time in fleet on rent growth are a touch ahead of our expectation for the remainder of the year, and maybe I'll offer up
componenttext: Sure, Tim. Just the way we characterize it is that July rate is very much in line with our expectation for the remainder of the year. Time in fleet on rent growth are a touch ahead of our expectation for the remainder of the year, and maybe I'll offer up a little bit more here. Your natural question is what is that expectation built? We're not going to give the exact number for the month of July, but our expectation for the rate sequentially over the month remaining in this year are flat to down slightly in each of the remaining months. So that gives you a little bit better frame for the rate expectation.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015

componenttext: When you think about the flat to down slightly for rate sequentially, how would you compare the rate expectations for the nonoil and gas exposed places to as opposed to the oil and gas branches?

componenttextpreview: Tim, this is Matt. That's a great question. I would say, they would fair better as they have. They've been almost over -- a little over 0.5. point better in the second quarter and we expect to see that combination. And the flat to down, there could be som
componenttext: Tim, this is Matt. That's a great question. I would say, they would fair better as they have. They've been almost over -- a little over 0.5. point better in the second quarter and we expect to see that combination. And the flat to down, there could be some lumpiness in there. But if you do the math, that needs to happen for us to reach our current guidance. And if there's more it to be had out there, as Mike stated, we will go after and we do think the opportunity will be in the nonoil and gas sectors.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I want to go back to the CapEx discussion. I mean, I appreciate that the company wants to be positioned for an improving environment. But I'm really kind of struggling with the way -- kind of the way that you frame the second half for rental rates and
componenttext: So I want to go back to the CapEx discussion. I mean, I appreciate that the company wants to be positioned for an improving environment. But I'm really kind of struggling with the way -- kind of the way that you frame the second half for rental rates and fleet utilization, I'm just struggling with why can you bring the second half CapEx number down. I mean, do you have a line of sight that you really feel like you need the equipment for the start of next year? I just -- given the rate and utilization outlook that we're looking at for the for third and fourth quarter, I'm just trying to reconcile why wouldn't you bring the CapEx down further at least for the second half of this year. And as kind of a tie-in into that question, you brought your long-term -- longer-term rate guidance down from 3% to 2%. And I would think that one of the ways that you could ensure that the rate stays higher is with less having upward pressure on fleet utilization. So I'm just trying to tie this all of this together, if you could.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Seth, this is Mike. It's a great question and it's one that we've been debated internally here for the last few weeks, actually, I would to the last few months. But I think we have to start, let me break down the CapEx for you, to begin with. Of the $1.6
componenttext: Seth, this is Mike. It's a great question and it's one that we've been debated internally here for the last few weeks, actually, I would to the last few months. But I think we have to start, let me break down the CapEx for you, to begin with. Of the $1.6 billion of rental CapEx, if you take away the inflation adjusted replacement CapEx of $1.14 billion, that leaves you with the growth capital of about $460 million. This is all seen in our investor deck that we have out there. We will spend of that $460 million, we'll spend $70 million of that this year to refurbishments and to our -- for our rental assets and the investments in our GPS our telematics for the fleet. So this is rounded. And that -- this leaves us about $400 million. That is split evenly between our specialty business and our-centric business. As I mentioned, our specialty business is doing quite well, and we're funding the 10 [ph] starts that we started. We have a more to go this year. That's a high-margin business, high return. And it also provides an entanglement with our customer base. So now we're talking about roughly $200 million for the Gen Rent. And we're funding the growth really goes into our national key accounts business, we've had some new wins and we're also investing in high time you devised assets. But when you think about investment, we don't think about just as a point in time, we're investing in what we think is a cycle that has multiple years of growth ahead of us. And I also want to point out, you mentioned us dropping our CapEx this year. I'll point out in the investor deck that we also dropped it going into next year and that's always subject to change. Just as the -- as we go through this year, and we think about next year and when we go into December and when we come out of the investment community, we'll update you. If we think that the worst is behind us completely and there's some rational behavior is going on, and we can see more, we're going to post more. But that said, we're actually very comfortable with our investment plan. As far as the rates are concerned, just to addressed that, yes, you're right, it declined. And if you recall, when it talked about rate, people are asking me -- used to ask me when we were coming out of every session, Mike, how do you see this? Will we went price margins improve NUC utilization then rate. Rate has been impacted but time utilization because of the influx, we're working through that as we go through the back half of this year. Now I will tell you, quite honestly, Seth, if we have put adjust next year, we will. But I just don't think about it as a point in time. I think it is a continuum because if we buy these assets for the life cycle and it's really comes on to a judgment call. And this is how we debated this and this is where we came out. And we're comfortable with it at this point in time.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015

componenttext: I appreciate that Mike. When we support the business, we would talk about -- so you did almost 69% utilization last year and we used to talk about line of sight our runway to pushing it out over 70%. It just seem like by adding this fleet, you're moving away from that objective and in congestion with that, the rate is coming down. So it just seems like there's at the minimum an opportunity here for the second half the year-to-date CapEx down and just sort of wait and see how things progress. Because really, no but in no know so the oral is going to play out. Are you locked into contracts that are -- this $200 [ph] of Gen Rent, is that a -- are those deals that you can't get out? Or you really feel have line of sight things will get better in the first half of next year, there are specific customers that are teed up for this equipment?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I would start part of it and I'll ask Matt to chime in. Our National Accounts represents about 40% of our total business and it's up 7% in the quarter. These are contractual long-term obligations for us. So line of sight on those is pretty long in c
componenttext: Well, I would start part of it and I'll ask Matt to chime in. Our National Accounts represents about 40% of our total business and it's up 7% in the quarter. These are contractual long-term obligations for us. So line of sight on those is pretty long in comparison to the rest of the industry. I'll ask Matt to talk about incentivization and some of the dynamics.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure, Seth. As Mike said, that additional $200 million flexibility to take that away without the risk of long-term relationships and long-term revenue and accretive positive good return revenue. So that's why we came to that decision. But when you pa
componenttext: Yes, sure, Seth. As Mike said, that additional $200 million flexibility to take that away without the risk of long-term relationships and long-term revenue and accretive positive good return revenue. So that's why we came to that decision. But when you parse out the gap year-over-year between -- which about 150 basis points when you look at our full year guidance this year versus our full year actual this year, half of that is call it we made continued our path on pump. So we've got a little over $70 million income assets that would that business being down, we could monetize if we thought that was the right long-term decisions. But what we want to fund the additional cold starts growth as well as candidly, not fire sell assets that have plenty of time light left on them and will have value for us long-term as we see these other recovery for that business production investment we made for it longer-term. So that's half of that 130 bps of year-over-year decline. Bill have pointed out we moved $125 million of assets out of the oil and gas. That's only 2/3 what we have to do. We have about another $60 million that we have to move out in the balance of this quarter. And we've had action plans, individual assets identified. When you tie those 2 components together, those are -- that's the drag, that's the 1.3 year-over-year drag that we're dealing with. And it's not unfortunately, as simple of us saying, we're not going to buy the remaining $200 million of high time assets in Gen Rent business and replace him with those assets that are dragging the time down. And that's why it looks a little dislocated at this look at it from afar but when you dig into the detail, which we've obviously done, we're comfortable with our plan.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Bill. We're human beings caution probably we have a view of rates starting the year. We had a view of rates at April, and both were wrong. So we thought a very deep and hard about what we expect for the remainder of this year. And that's infl
componenttext: Yes, this is Bill. We're human beings caution probably we have a view of rates starting the year. We had a view of rates at April, and both were wrong. So we thought a very deep and hard about what we expect for the remainder of this year. And that's influenced by our experience. So how much? It's hard to put a number on it. We feel like this is a realistic view. Now, look, I mean we set about 0.5%. Could it be 0.4% or 0.3%? Yes. Could it be 0.6% or 0.7%? Yes. So it's fair to say our thinking was influenced by the experience and we don't want to be in a position of missing this time to be brutally honest about it.

componenttext: I would say when you break it down market-by-market and you see more half of our sequential rate improvement in Q2 as opposed to the overall company and 9 of our 14 regions have shown year-over-year growth. We see that there are still markets that even absorbing extra capacity in the near-term are performing well. And that's what gives us that confidence that we can continue on the path that we've reguided to. And more importantly, that '16 and '17 end markets feel strong for us.

componenttext: Yes, I would like to point out on the investor deck, which by the way we've broken to 2 segments so that it's easy for people to go through. One is a financial deck and one is the background information. But out on Page 6, you'll see a nonoil and gas location. And you'll see the greater than 20% Upstream exposure, and the ones with less than 20%. And the OEC on rent build is very similar to what the pattern you saw last year. You'll see that in the oil patch, particularly in the Upstream, you'll see the bifurcation of where it actually pivoted in March. And the track drag spend but it seems to have moderated as for us the timing. One thing we will tell you according to Rouse is for the company, for United Rentals, we still lead the industry in our peer group on time utilization. That being said, we're not done. We've got more to do a mass Matt mentioned. We've got some more assets entered the going to get that. So this is moving hasn't played out yet but we're focused on it.

And when my it is sort of wash up from on access equipment respect if we and rates could positively turn positive year-on-year.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Nicole, it's Bill. Our '16 forecast does assume rates turn positive year-over-year in '16. And so the note that we put in the investor deck about it averaging 2% thereafter, reflects a positive year-over-year in '16 and then a greater positive and '17. An
componenttext: Nicole, it's Bill. Our '16 forecast does assume rates turn positive year-over-year in '16. And so the note that we put in the investor deck about it averaging 2% thereafter, reflects a positive year-over-year in '16 and then a greater positive and '17. And so that's the profile that we expect. The fit absorption issue that we're playing through right now, we talked about it being 2015 or, perhaps, early 2016 phenomena. And that's shaping our thinking about how we approach allocating fleet capital and so forth.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: There's nothing major and specific that we have baked into our forecast for the second half. And so if you want to interpret that as being conservative, I guess you could reasonably do it that way. But we don't want to get too far done the road of forecas
componenttext: There's nothing major and specific that we have baked into our forecast for the second half. And so if you want to interpret that as being conservative, I guess you could reasonably do it that way. But we don't want to get too far done the road of forecasting higher flow-through unless and until we've got a better sense of where that's going to come from. And so we put the best -- our best foot forward on our flow-through, on our comments year-to-date and we're going to work really hard on it in the second half.

componenttextpreview: When you take a step back and look at the key metric, rental rates growth slowed down such declined, time utilization reduction, CapEx reduction, those are typically classic signs of a peak in the cycle. What gives you confidence we're not at peak in the
componenttext: When you take a step back and look at the key metric, rental rates growth slowed down such declined, time utilization reduction, CapEx reduction, those are typically classic signs of a peak in the cycle. What gives you confidence we're not at peak in the cycle? And potentially a peak that's been induced by overfeeding or oversupply?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, that's a great question. So let me step back and say, if you recall that used margins continue to be very strong. But more importantly, we took a look at and if you take a look at just the U.S. economy forecast growth in '15, '16 and '17, in real GD
componenttext: Well, that's a great question. So let me step back and say, if you recall that used margins continue to be very strong. But more importantly, we took a look at and if you take a look at just the U.S. economy forecast growth in '15, '16 and '17, in real GDP, streams to improve critical. When you take a look at residential investment, business investment and even the state and local investment, it's supposed to improve. Step forward, take a look at what Dodge has put out and we have this all broken down into our investor deck. Construction, excluding utility and gas plants, it's going to be up in '15 by 9%, projected 12% and 16% and 14% in '17. And then we even break it down by IHS, word Israel construction growth by sector over the outlying years. Again, all public information, all the independent and on the fits our primary all affect our primary goals for of nonres construction, which is a big catalyst for our industry, remains positive. So over time, we see that to continue to play out. With regards to the fleet, I've talked about this, I understand the refleeting. I get it from all of the independent independence, they have been somewhat blocked out for some period of time. They don't have an endless supply of capital available to them. So -- and I also think that with the Rouse information, 55, at least 55 participants aside from United Rentals participate in this. So they have real data, they have real information they, which they can help such their business better today than ever before. And I believe that they signed up for the so that you can understand how the contractor better returns, holiday contract their cash flow so that it get themselves in the situations when the cycle does turn. So I don't see the type of cycle turning yet. I think there's still multiple years ahead of us, and we tend to agree with the experts that are out there.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Nick, this is Matt. As we obviously saw in May, our largest year-over-year and sequential utilization gap, it did so it'd have a drag on the overall business. We since rebounded from that. So it's really had some impact on the first half results. Bu
componenttext: Sure, Nick, this is Matt. As we obviously saw in May, our largest year-over-year and sequential utilization gap, it did so it'd have a drag on the overall business. We since rebounded from that. So it's really had some impact on the first half results. But candidly, we don't think that, that was the major reason. It was in a specific period of time but I think that the overall dislocation of the the fleet that was brought in faster-than-expected decline in a big end market of oil and gas has probably had more to do with it. But May weather was really no help and we did see a Robert largest dislocation, we were over 170 bps down year-over-year in the month of May and then rebounded up to 130 bps in the month of June.

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015

componenttext: Okay, and then last question here. I wondered if you can just talk a bit about the acquisition landscape right now, and whether or not the current environment is giving you any pause?

headline: United Rentals, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Look, we're in a very good session. But right now, we're giving $1 billion of share repurchases back to stockholders. to this is giving us a lot of flexibility to do acquisitions. But I will tell you that we are have a high bar, and we look at it these th
componenttext: Look, we're in a very good session. But right now, we're giving $1 billion of share repurchases back to stockholders. to this is giving us a lot of flexibility to do acquisitions. But I will tell you that we are have a high bar, and we look at it these things. We passed on a lot. And some that we've been intrigued by. But it's ongoing. I would just say the weaker that's out there is not going to anticipate. if it is important for everyone to understand. But this company has not changed its view or its goals of where we are and where the we enter to go on returns and whether it be capital, whether it be acquisitions, they all going to the same bucket. Acquisitions have to be on their own merit as to strategically, financially and culturally why we would do it.
